{{Infobox character | colour = | colour text = | name = | series = | image = | caption = | first = [[At the Villa Rose (novel)|At the Villa Rose]] | last = [[The House in Lordship Lane]] | cause = | creator = [[A. E. W. Mason]] | portrayer = [[Teddy Arundell]]
[[Richard Cooper (actor)|Richard Cooper]]
[[Dennis Neilson-Terry]]
[[Kenneth Kent]]
[[Oskar Homolka]] | episode = | nickname = | alias = | species = | gender = Male | occupation = Police Officer | title = Inspector | family = | significantother = | children = | relatives = | religion = | nationality = French }} '''Inspector Gabriel Hanaud''' is a fictional character depicted in a series of 6 novels and a short story by the British writer [[A. E. W. Mason]]. He has been described as the "first major fiction police detective of the Twentieth Century".Pitts p.85 He was modelled on two real-life heads of the [[Paris]] [[Sûreté]], Macé and Goron.Queen p.67 [[Émile Gaboriau]]'s [[Monsieur Lecoq]] was also an acknowledged inspiration.Bargainnier p.37-38 Mason wanted to physically differentiate Hanaud from [[Sherlock Holmes]] as much as possible, and so he made him stout and broad-shouldered in contrast to Holmes who was thin.Bargainnier p.38 He often relies on [[psychological]] methods to solve cases.Bargainnier p.36 Hanaud is assisted by his friend, the fastidious Mr Julius Ricardo, a former [[City of London]] financier. Hanaud makes his first appearance in the 1910 story ''[[At the Villa Rose (novel)|At the Villa Rose]]'' set in the south of France. He appeared in a further four novels, and several short stories. His last appearance was in the 1946 novel ''[[The House in Lordship Lane]]''. Hanaud was portrayed on screen several times – with adaptations of ''[[At the Villa Rose (novel)|At the Villa Rose]]'' and its sequel ''[[The House of the Arrow (novel)|The House of the Arrow]]''. He has been seen as one of a number of influences on the creation of [[Agatha Christie]]'s Belgian detective [[Hercule Poirot]]. ==Hanaud novels== * ''[[At the Villa Rose (novel)|At the Villa Rose]]'' (1910) * ''The Affair at the Semiramis Hotel'' (1917) (Novelette) * ''[[The House of the Arrow (novel)|The House of the Arrow]]'' (1924) * ''[[The Prisoner in the Opal]]'' (1928) * ''[[They Wouldn't Be Chessmen]]'' (1934) * ''"The Ginger King"'' (1940) (Short Story) * ''[[The House in Lordship Lane]]'' (1946) * ''[[Inspector Hanaud's Investigations]]'' (1931) (omnibus volume of first three novels) ==Film adaptations== * ''[[At the Villa Rose (1920 film)|At the Villa Rose]]'' (1920) starring [[Teddy Arundell]] * ''[[At the Villa Rose (1930 film)|At the Villa Rose]]'' (1930) starring [[Austin Trevor]] * ''[[The House of the Arrow (1930 film)|The House of the Arrow]]'' (1930) starring [[Dennis Neilson-Terry]] * ''[[La Maison de la Fléche]]'' (The House of the Arrow) (1930) * ''[[At the Villa Rose (1940 film)|At the Villa Rose]]'' (1940) starring [[Kenneth Kent]] * ''[[The House of the Arrow (1940 film)|The House of the Arrow]]'' (1940) starring Kenneth Kent * ''[[The House of the Arrow (1953 film)|The House of the Arrow]]'' (1953) starring [[Oskar Homolka]] ==References== ==Bibliography== * Bargainnier, Earl F. ''Twelve Englishmen of mystery''. Bowling Green University Popular Press, 1984. * Pitts, Michael R. ''Famous Movie Detectives III''. Scarecrow Press, 2004 * Queen, Ellery ''Queen's Quorum: a History of the Detective-Crime Short Story''. New York, 1969. {{A. E. W. Mason}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hanaud, Inspector}} [[Category:Fictional police detectives|Hanaud, Inspector]] [[Category:Fictional French people|Hanaud, Inspector]] [[Category:Series of books|Inspector Hanaud]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1910]] [[Category:Characters in British novels of the 20th century]] {{novel-char-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} [[File:Othello and Desdemona (Fradelle, c.1827) crop.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Othello (character)|Othello, the Moor]] and [[Desdemona]], his [[Republic of Venice|Venetian]] wife, from [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Othello]]'' ([[Henri Jean-Baptiste Victoire Fradelle|Fradelle]], c.1827, detail)]]
'''Interracial marriage''' is a form of [[marriage]] outside a specific social group ([[exogamy]]) involving spouses who belong to different socially-defined [[Race (classification of human beings)|races]] or [[Ethnic group#Ethnicity and race|racialized ethnicities]]. In the past, it was outlawed in the [[United States of America]] and in [[South Africa]] as [[miscegenation]]. It became legal in the entire United States in 1967 when the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] ruled in the case ''[[Loving v. Virginia]]'' that race-based restrictions on marriages violated the [[Equal Protection Clause]] of the [[United States Constitution]].
== Legality == {{Further information|Marriage laws|Anti-miscegenation laws}} Many jurisdictions have had regulations banning or restricting not just interracial marriage but also interracial sexual relations, including [[Nazi Germany|Germany during the Nazi period]], [[South Africa under apartheid]], and many states in the [[United States]] prior to [[Loving v. Virginia|a 1967 Supreme Court decision]].
== Americas ==
=== United States === {{Main article|Interracial marriage in the United States}} [[File:US miscegenation.svg|thumb|320px|U.S States, by the date of repeal of anti-miscegenation laws: {{legend|#d3d3d3|No laws passed}} {{legend|#5b9e39|Repealed before 1887}} {{legend|#f3ee66|Repealed between 1948 and 1967}} {{legend|#cc2f2f|Overturned on 12 June 1967}}]]
Interracial marriage in the [[United States]] has been fully legal in all [[U.S. state]]s since the [[Loving v. Virginia|1967 Supreme Court decision]] that deemed anti-miscegenation laws unconstitutional, with many states choosing to legalize interracial marriage at much earlier dates. Anti-miscegenation laws have played a large role in defining racial identity and enforcing the racial hierarchy. The United States has many ethnic and racial groups, and interracial marriage is fairly common among most of them. Interracial marriages increased from 2% of married couples in 1970 to 7% in 2005<ref name="Two or More" /><ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/18090277/ns/us_news-life/t/after-years-interracial-marriage-flourishing/ Interracial marriage flourishes in U.S. – US news – Life – Race & ethnicity]. MSNBC (2007-04-15). Retrieved 9 May 2012.</ref> and 8.4% in 2010.<ref name=pew2012>Wang, Wendy (16 February 2012) [http://www.pewsocialtrends.org/2012/02/16/the-rise-of-intermarriage/ "The Rise of Intermarriage"] [[Pew Research Center]]</ref>
According to a Pew Research Center analysis of census data conducted in 2013, 12% of newlyweds married someone of a different race. (This share does not take into account the "interethnic" marriages between Hispanics and non-Hispanics).<ref name="pewresearch.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2015/06/12/interracial-marriage-who-is-marrying-out/ |title=Interracial marriage: Who is ‘marrying out’? |date=12 June 2015 |website=[[Pew Research Center]] |accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref> And, most Americans say they approve of racial or ethnic intermarriage – not just in the abstract, but in their own families. More than six-in-ten say it would be fine with them if a family member told them they were going to marry someone from any of three major race/ethnic groups other than their own.<ref>{{cite web |last=Wang |first=Wendy |title=The Rise of Intermarriage Rates, Characteristics Vary by Race and Gender |url=http://www.pewsocialtrends.org/2012/02/16/the-rise-of-intermarriage/ |work=PewSocialTrends.org |publisher=Pew Research |accessdate=21 January 2014}}</ref>
Some racial groups are more likely to intermarry than others. Of the 3.6 million adults who got married in 2013, 58% of Native Americans, 28% of Asians, 19% of blacks and 7% of whites have a spouse whose race was different from their own. The overall numbers mask significant gender gaps within some racial groups. Among blacks, men are much more likely than women to marry someone of a different race. Fully a quarter of black men who got married in 2013 married someone who was not black. Only 12% of black women married outside of their race. For Asians, the gender pattern goes in the opposite direction: Asian women are much more likely than Asian men to marry someone of a different race. Among newlyweds in 2013, 37% of Asian women married someone who was not Asian, while 16% of Asian men married outside of their race. However, Asian women are more likely to marry Asian men than any other men of different ethnic background. Native Americans have the highest interracial marriage rate among all single-race groups. Women are slightly more likely to "marry out" than men in this group: 61% of Native American female newlyweds married outside their race, compared with 54% of Native American male newlyweds.<ref name="pewresearch.org"/>
Although the anti-miscegenation laws have been revoked, the social stigma related to Black interracial marriages still exists in today's society although to a much lesser degree. Research by Tucker and Mitchell-Kerman from 1990 has shown that Blacks intermarry far less than any other non-White group<ref>{{cite journal |author=Tucker, M. B. |author2=Mitchell-Kernan, C. |jstor=352851 |title=New trends in black American interracial marriage: The social structural context |year=1990 |journal=Journal of Marriage and Family |volume=52 |issue=1 |pages=209–218 |doi=10.2307/352851}}</ref> and in 2010, only 17.1% of Blacks married interracially, a rate far lower than the rates for Hispanics and Asians.<ref name=pew2012 /> Black interracial marriages in particular engender problems associated with racist attitudes and perceived relational inappropriateness.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Hibbler, D. K. |author2=Shinew, K. J. |year=2002 |title=Interracial couples' experience of leisure: A social network approach |journal=Journal of Leisure Research |volume=34 |page=1357156 |url=http://eblackcu.net/portal/archive/files/hibbler-2002pdf_bbe897259a_e1a09ef5df.pdf}}</ref> There is also a sharp gender imbalance to Black interracial marriages: In 2008, 22% of all black male newlyweds married interracially while only 9% of black female newlyweds married outside their race, making them one of the least likely of any race or gender to marry outside their race and the least likely to get married at all.<ref>Davis, Linsey (4 June 2010) [http://abcnews.go.com/WN/Media/black-women-marry-interracial-marriage-common/story?id=10830719#.UZAavkLD-dI Interracial Marriage More Common Than Ever, but Black Women Still Lag]. ABC News</ref>
From the mid 19th to 20th centuries, many black people and ethnic Mexicans intermarried with each other in the Lower Rio Grande Valley in South Texas (mostly in Cameron County and Hidalga County). In Cameron County, 38% of black people were interracially married (7/18 families) while in Hidalgo County the number was 72% (18/25 families). These two counties had the highest rates of interracial marriages involving at least one black spouse in the United States. The vast majority of these marriages involved black men marrying ethnic Mexican women or first generation Tejanas (Texas-born women of Mexican descent). Since ethnic Mexicans were considered white by Texas officials and the U.S. government, such marriages were a violation of the state's anti-miscegenation laws. Yet, there is no evidence that anyone in South Texas was prosecuted for violating this law. The rates of this interracial marriage dynamic can be traced back to when black men moved into the Lower Rio Grande Valley after the Civil War ended. They married into ethnic Mexican families and joined other black people who found sanctuary on the U.S./Mexico border.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blackpast.org/perspectives/border-love-rio-grande-african-american-men-and-latinas-rio-grande-valley-south-texas-1 |title=Border Love on the Rio Grande: African American Men and Latinas in the Rio Grande Valley of South Texas (1850–1940) |publisher=The Black Past |date=2003-06-10 |accessdate=11 April 2014}}</ref>
The Chinese that migrated were almost entirely of Cantonese origin. Hundreds of thousands of Chinese men in the U.S, mostly of Cantonese origin from Taishan migrated to the United States. [[Anti-miscegenation laws]] in many states prohibited Chinese men from marrying white women.<ref>[http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=283998 Chin, Gabriel and Hrishi Karthikeyan, (2002) Asian Law Journal vol. 9 "Preserving Racial Identity: Population Patterns and the Application of Anti-Miscegenation Statutes to Asian Americans, 1910–1950"]. Papers.ssrn.com. Retrieved 29 January 2012.</ref> After the [[Emancipation Proclamation]], many intermarriages in some states were not recorded and historically, Chinese American men married African American women in high proportions to their total marriage numbers due to few Chinese American women being in the United States. After the Emancipation Proclamation, many Chinese Americans immigrated to the Southern states, particularly Arkansas, to work on plantations. For example, in 1880, the tenth [[US Census]] of [[Louisiana]] alone counted 57% of interracial marriages between these Chinese to be with black and 43% to be with white women.<ref name="The United States">{{cite web |url=http://www.colorq.org/MeltingPot/article.aspx?d=America&x=ChineseBlacks |title=The United States |work=Chinese blacks in the Americas |publisher=Color Q World |accessdate=15 July 2008}}</ref> Between 20 and 30 percent of the Chinese who lived in Mississippi married black women before 1940.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Susan Dente Ross |author2=Paul Martin Lester |title=Images That Injure: Pictorial Stereotypes in the Media |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cpIHIKUS-e0C&pg=PA144 |accessdate=2 March 2012 |date=19 April 2011 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=978-0-313-37892-8 |pages=144–}}</ref> In a genetic study of 199 samples from African American males found one belong to haplogroup O2a ( or 0.5% )<ref>Evaluation of Group Genetic Ancestry of Populations from Philadelphia and Dakar in the Context of Sex-Biased Admixture in the Americas Stefflova K, Dulik MC, Pai AA, Walker AH, Zeigler-Johnson CM, Gueye SM, Schurr TG, Rebbeck TR – PLoS ONE (2009). [http://openi.nlm.nih.gov/detailedresult.php?img=2776971_pone.0007842.g002&req=4]</ref> It was discovered by historian [[Henry Louis Gates, Jr]] in the ''[[African American Lives]]'' documentary miniseries that [[NASA]] astronaut [[Mae Jemison]] has a significant (above 10%) genetic [[East Asia]]n admixture. Gates speculated that the intermarriage/relations between migrant Chinese workers during the 19th century and black, or African-American slaves or ex-slaves may have contributed to her ethnic genetic make-up. In the mid 1850s, 70 to 150 Chinese were living in New York City and 11 of them married Irish women. In 1906 the ''New York Times'' (6 August) reported that 300 white women (Irish American) were married to Chinese men in New York, with many more cohabited. In 1900, based on Liang research, of the 120,000 men in more than 20 Chinese communities in the United States, he estimated that one out of every twenty Chinese men (Cantonese) was married to white women.<ref>{{cite book |author=Benson Tong |title=Asian American children: a historical handbook and guide |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uK6xhcu-4hAC&pg=PA38 |accessdate=2 March 2012 |year=2004 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |isbn=978-0-313-33042-1 |pages=38–}}</ref> In the 1960s census showed 3500 Chinese men married to white women and 2900 Chinese women married to white men. It also showed 300 Chinese men married to Black women and vice versa 100.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=-im2X0hbpv8C&pg=PA180&dq=Chinese+men+white+women+3500+++america&hl=en&sa=X&ei=yy2XUb_ZM4HgOO2lgdgE&ved=0CD4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Chinese%20men%20white%20women%203500%20%20%20america&f=false Love's revolution: interracial marriage] by Maria P.P. Root. Page 180</ref>
==== Hawaii ==== The majority of the [[Hawaiian Chinese]] were [[Cantonese people|Cantonese]] migrants from [[Guangdong]] with minority of [[Hakka people|Hakka]] descent also from Guangdong. If all people with Chinese ancestry in Hawaii (including the Chinese-Hawaiians) are included, they form about 1/3 of Hawaii's entire population. Many thousands of them married women of Hawaiian, Hawaiian/European and European origin. A large percentage of the Chinese men married Hawaiian and Hawaiian/European women, while a minority married white women in Hawaii who were of [[Portuguese American|Portuguese]] descent. The 12,592 Asiatic-Hawaiians enumerated in 1930 were the result of Chinese men intermarrying with Hawaiian and part Hawaiian/Europeans. Most Asiatic-Hawaiian men also married Hawaiians and European women (and vice versa). On the census, some Chinese with little "native blood" would be classified as Chinese – not as Asiatic-Hawaiians – due to "dilution of native blood". Intermarriage started to decline in the 1920s.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~db=all~content=a904831799 |title=Interethnic Marriage and Divorce in Hawaii A Panel Study of 1968 First Marriages |author=Schwertfeger, Margaret M. |year=1982 |publisher=Kessinger Publishing}}</ref> Portuguese and other Caucasian women married Chinese men.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_j2lXoxMIiAC&pg=PA254 |title=Divorce: crisis, challenge, or relief? |author1=David Anthony Chiriboga |author2=Linda S. Catron |year=1991 |publisher=NYU Press |page=254 |isbn=978-0-8147-1450-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://www.google.com/?id=AUL3iXlwKQgC&pg=PA58 |title=Intermarriage in the United States, Volume 5 |author1=Cretser, Gary A. |author2=Leon, Joseph J. |year=1982 |publisher=Psychology Press |page=58 |isbn=978-0-917724-60-2}}</ref> The unions between Chinese men and Portuguese women resulted in children of mixed Chinese Portuguese parentage, called Chinese-Portuguese. For two years to 30 June 1933, 38 of these children who were born were classified as pure Chinese because their fathers were Chinese.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GrvXiBNOsO0C&pg=PA32 |title=Interracial Marriage in Hawaii |author=Adams, Romanzo |year=2005 |publisher=Kessinger Publishing |page=396 |isbn=978-1-4179-9268-3}}</ref> A large amount of mingling took place between Chinese and Portuguese, Chinese men married Portuguese, Spanish, Hawaiian, Caucasian-Hawaiian, etc.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://www.google.com/?id=hzoXAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA27 |title=Bulletin, Issues 13–18 |author=United States Bureau of Education |year=1921 |publisher=U.S. G.P.O. |page=27}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0hSmD_8bhpwC&pg=PA27 |title=Bulletin, Issue 16 |author=United States. Office of Education |year=1920 |publisher=U.S. Dept. of Health, Education, and Welfare, Office of Education |page=27}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dewAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA492 |title=American journal of physical anthropology, Volume 3 |author=American Association of Physical Anthropologists, Wistar Institute of Anatomy and Biology |year=1920 |publisher=A. R. Liss |page=492}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://www.google.com/?id=AUL3iXlwKQgC&pg=PA53 |title=Intermarriage in the United States, Volume 5 |author1=Cretser, Gary A. |author2=Leon, Joseph J. |year=1982 |publisher=Routledge |page=111 |isbn=978-0-917724-60-2}}</ref> Only one Chinese man was recorded marrying an American woman.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://www.google.com/?id=fsAUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA42 |title=The Journal of heredity, Volume 10 |author=American Genetic Association |year=1919 |publisher=American Genetic Association |page=42}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pf_zAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA42 |title=J hered, Volume 10 |author=American Genetic Association |year=1919 |publisher=American Genetic Association |page=42}}</ref> Chinese men in Hawaii also married Puerto Rican, Portuguese, Japanese, Greek, and half-white women.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_7a0sWazYH8C&pg=PA988 |title=New Outlook, Volume 81 |author=Smith, Alfred Emanuel |year=1905 |publisher=Outlook Publishing Company, Inc. |page=988}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=57_QAAAAMAAJ |title=The Outlook, Volume 81 |year=1905 |publisher=Outlook Co. |page=988}}</ref>
=== Canada === In Canada, 2011, 4.6% of all civil unions are interracial ones, an 18% increase from 2006 (3.9%), and a 77% increase from 1991 (2.6%).<ref name="StatCan2011">[http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/nhs-enm/2011/as-sa/99-010-x/99-010-x2011003_3-eng.cfm Mixed unions in Canada (2011)]. Retrieved 22 June 2014.</ref> [[Vancouver]] reported the highest rate of interracial unions, at 9.6%, and [[Toronto]] in second place at 8.2%. Major census metropolitan areas had higher frequencies of mixed unions (6.0%) compared to areas that were not classified as such (1.0%). Younger people were more likely to be in a mixed union; the highest proportion of couples in mixed unions was among persons aged 25 to 34 (7.7%), 35 to 44 (6.8%), 15 to 24 (6.1%), 45 to 54 (4.1%), and 55 and over (2.7%).<ref name="StatCan2011" />
The 2006 study had an interesting find, that people born in Canada were more likely to marry someone of another race as opposed to those who immigrated there;<ref name="StatCan">[http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/11-008-x/2010001/article/11143-eng.htm#a3 A portrait of couples in mixed unions]. Retrieved 28 January 2014.</ref> only 12% of first generation immigrant visible minorities were in a mixed union, this figure is higher for second generation immigrants (51%) and three or more generation immigrants (69%). There are a few examples of this: # 63% of Canadian-born Blacks (who were in couples) were in mixed unions, while the numbers for Blacks born in the Caribbean and Bermuda (17%), and Africa (13%) were much lower percentages. # For Chinese people born in Canada, 54% (who were in couples) were with someone non-Chinese (it's not noted if this figure refers to anyone who is not East Asian (race), or just not Chinese (nationality)), compared to only 3% of those born in China who immigrated to Canada. # 33% of South Asian Canadians who were born in Canada, were in a mixed union, compared to only 3% of those who were born in South Asia.
One theory for this may include that those who immigrate as adults, may have already found a partner before immigrating to Canada.<ref name="StatCan" />
Certain visible minority groups had higher rates of being in mixed unions; * 78.7% of [[Japanese Canadian|Japanese]] * 64.9% of multiracial people * 48.2% of [[Latin American Canadian|Latin Americans]] * 40.2% of [[Black Canadian|Blacks]] * 29.8% of [[Filipino Canadian|Filipinos]] * 25.4% of [[Arab Canadian|Arabs]] / [[West Asians]] * 22.5% of [[Korean Canadian|Koreans]] * 21.9% of [[Southeast Asians]] (other than Filipinos) * 19.4% of [[Chinese Canadian|Chinese]] * 13.0% of [[South Asian Canadian|South Asians]] * 52.4% of other groups;
There are no statistics that show data for [[European Canadians|Whites]] or [[Aboriginal Canadians|Aboriginals]].
The 2006 study also stated that same-sex couples are about 2.5 times more likely to be in an interracial marriage as opposed to opposite-sex couples, 9.8% of same-sex marriages are interracial.<ref name="StatCan" /> There were some theories as to why; [[same-sex marriage in Canada]] become legal in 2005, whereas opposite sex marriage was always legal, and it also mentions that same-sex couples are more likely to be in [[common-law marriage]]s, and common-law marriages had a higher frequency of mixed unions.
One study done by Reg Bibby found that 92% of Canadians are accepting of interracial marriages.<ref>[http://www.vancouversun.com/life/Douglas+Todd+forces+against+mixed+marriage/8939561/story.html Douglas Todd: The forces for and against mixed marriage]. Retrieved 28 January 2014.</ref>
{{See also|Metis people (Canada)}}
=== Latin America === In [[Latin America]], most of the population are descended from [[Amerindians]], [[Europe]]ans and [[Africans]]. They formed the [[Mestizo]] and [[Mulatto]] populations that populate the countries in Latin America. Intermarriage and inter-relations occurred on a larger scale than most places in the world. In some countries, [[Asian people|Asian]] immigrants have also intermarried among the groups. About 300,000 [[Cantonese people|Cantonese]] coolies and migrants (almost all males) were shipped 1849 to 1874 Latin America, many of them intermarried and cohabited with the Black, Mestizo, and European population of Cuba, Peru, Guyana, Trinidad. Around 20,000 Mostly Cantonese and some [[Hakka people|Hakka]] coolies migrated to Jamaica, Guyana, Trinidad. Many of them also intermarried with Black women and East Indian women. Unlike in Trinidad Tobago and Guyana who were predominantly Cantonese men who intermarried with Black women and Indian women. In Jamaica, the Chinese who married Black women were mostly Hakka. According to the 1946 Census from Jamaica and Trinidad alone, 12,394 Chinese were located between [[Jamaica]] and [[Trinidad]]. 5,515 of those who lived in [[Jamaica]] were Chinese Jamaican and another 3,673 were Chinese-Trinidadians living in [[Trinidad]].<ref name="The United States"/> In Jamaica and other Caribbean nations as well many Chinese males over past generations took up African wives, gradually assimilating or absorbing many Chinese descendants into the African Caribbean community or the overall mixed-race community.<ref>[http://motherearthtravel.com/guyana/population.htm Population of Guyana]. Motherearthtravel.com. Retrieved 9 May 2012.</ref> In Guyana, the Chinese were mostly Cantonese men and who intermarried with the local women. Because almost all of the Chinese indentured immigrants were men, they tended to intermarry with both East Indians and Africans, and thus the Chinese of Guyana did not remain as physically distinct as other groups.<ref>[http://www.everyculture.com/Middle-America-Caribbean/Chinese-in-the-English-Speaking-Caribbean-Settlements.html: Chinese in the English-Speaking Caribbean – Settlements]. Everyculture.com. Retrieved 9 May 2012.</ref> Marriage among different Chinese language groups is rare; it is so rare that the any cases of it can be individually name. While intermarriage between Hakka Chinese and Indians hardly occur.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H_xtAAAAMAAJ&q=rarely+hakka+indian+intermarry&dq=rarely+hakka+indian+intermarry&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwil0_2M2cTSAhULJcAKHaoKDQoQ6AEIHDAA |title=Blood, sweat, and mahjong: family and enterprise in an overseas Chinese community |first=Ellen |last=Oxfeld |date=22 October 1993 |publisher=Cornell University Press |accessdate=22 October 2017 |via=Google Books}}</ref>
=== Guyana === In Guyana, the prospect of sexual relations with [[Indo-Guyanese|Indian]] women was at first unappealing to the mostly male [[Chinese Guyanese|Chinese]] migrants like in [[Mauritian of Chinese origin#Migration history|Mauritius]] although there was a lack of Chinese women, but eventually their attitude changed and Indian women and Chinese men established sexual relationships with each other.<ref>{{cite book |pages=272–273 |year=1995 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=McGill-Queen's Press – MQUP |volume=Volume 22 of McGill-Queen's studies in ethnic history |issn=0846-8869 |edition=illustrated |author=Brian L. Moore |quote= |location= |title=Cultural Power, Resistance, and Pluralism: Colonial Guyana, 1838–1900 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=cx_9-X_-smoC&pg=PA272&dq=Chinese+men+also+cohabited+with+Indian+women,+and+in+a+few+instances+those+women+even |isbn=0-7735-1354-X}}</ref> Chinese men had to marry women of other ethnicities due to the lack of Chinese women migrating to British Guiana.<ref>{{cite book |page= |pages= |year=1989 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=History Society |volume= |issn= |edition= |others=University of Guyana. History Society |quote= |location= |title=History Gazette, Issues 1-2; Issues 4-27 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=AuhsAAAAMAAJ&q=It+was+always+difficult+to+recruit+Chinese+women+to+emigrate+to+British+Guiana+and+thus+many+men+were+forced+to+find+wives+or+to+cohabit+with+women+of+other+races.&dq=It+was+always+difficult+to+recruit+Chinese+women+to+emigrate+to+British+Guiana+and+thus+many+men+were+forced+to+find+wives+or+to+cohabit+with+women+of+other+races. |isbn=0-7735-1354-X}}</ref> [[Creole peoples#Caribbean|Creole]] sexual relationships and marriages with Chinese and Indians was rare,<ref>{{cite book |page=181 |pages= |year=1987 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Gordon & Breach Science Publishers |volume=Volume 4 of Caribbean studies |issn=0275-5793 |edition=illustrated |author=Brian L. Moore |title=Race, Power, and Social Segmentation in Colonial Society: Guyana After Slavery, 1838–1891 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=35u9AAAAIAAJ&q=As+Wood+and+Brereton+found+for+Trinidad,172+so+too+in+Guyana,+interracial+marriage+and+miscegenation+were+rare,173+particularly+between+Indians+and+Chinese+on+one+hand+and+Creoles+on+the+other.174+Nevertheless,+as+early+as+1841,+some+Indians+were+found+to+cohabit+with+Creole&dq=As+Wood+and+Brereton+found+for+Trinidad,172+so+too+in+Guyana,+interracial+marriage+and+miscegenation+were+rare,173+particularly+between+Indians+and+Chinese+on+one+hand+and+Creoles+on+the+other.174+Nevertheless,+as+early+as+1841,+some+Indians+were+found+to+cohabit+with+Creole |isbn=0-677-21980-6}}</ref> however, more common was Indian women and Chinese men establishing sexual relations with each other and some Chinese men took their Indian wives back with them to China.<ref>{{cite book |page=182 |pages= |year=1987 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Gordon & Breach Science Publishers |volume=Volume 4 of Caribbean studies |issn=0275-5793 |edition=illustrated |author=Brian L. Moore |title=Race, Power, and Social Segmentation in Colonial Society: Guyana After Slavery, 1838–1891 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=35u9AAAAIAAJ&q=It+appears,+however,+that+cohabitation+between+Chinese+men+and+Indian+women+was+less+rare,+and+in+a+few+instances+the+women+even+accompanied+their+reputed+husbands+to+China.&dq=It+appears,+however,+that+cohabitation+between+Chinese+men+and+Indian+women+was+less+rare,+and+in+a+few+instances+the+women+even+accompanied+their+reputed+husbands+to+China. |isbn=0-677-21980-6}}</ref> Marriages between Indian women and Chinese men in 1892 numbered six as reported by Immigration Agent Gladwin.<ref>{{cite book |page=213 |pages= |year=2000 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Peepul Tree |volume= |issn= |edition=illustrated |author=D. A. Bisnauth |quote= |location= |title=The settlement of Indians in Guyana, 1890–1930 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=e-YYAAAAYAAJ&dq=In+1892%2C+Immigration+Agent+Gladwin+reported+just+six+marriages+between+Chinese+men+and+Indian+women.&q=1892+six+marriages |isbn=}}</ref> In Guyana, while marriages between Indian women and black African men is socially shameful to Indians, Chinese-Indian marriages are considered acceptable as reported by Joseph Nevadomsky in 1983.<ref>{{cite book |page=38 |pages= |year=2000 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=ProQuest |volume= |issn= |edition=illustrated |author=Preethy Sarah Samuel |others=Wayne State University. Sociology |quote= |location= |title=Cultural Continuity Or Assimilation in the Familial Domain of the Indo-Guyanese |url=https://books.google.com/?id=5j25gvLg5HUC&pg=PA38&dq=guyana+chinese+marry+indian+women |isbn=0-549-38762-5}}</ref> "Chiney-dougla" is the Indian Guyanese term for mixed Chinese-Indian children.<ref>{{cite book |page=209 |pages= |year=2002 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=Japan Center for Area Studies, National Museum of Ethnology |volume= |issn= |edition=illustrated |others=Kokuritsu Minzokugaku Hakubutsukan. Chiiki Kenkyū Kikaku Kōryū Sentā |quote= |location= |title=JCAS Symposium Series, Issue 13 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=r8JQAQAAIAAJ&q=If+a+child+is+from+Indian-Chinese+parentage,+%28s%29he+may+be+called+%27chiney-dougla.&dq=If+a+child+is+from+Indian-Chinese+parentage,+%28s%29he+may+be+called+%27chiney-dougla. |archiveurl=https://www.academia.edu/3850752/Intermarriage_Douglas_Creolization_ofIndians_in_Contemporary_Guyana_the_Rocky_Road_of_Ambiguity_and_Ambivalence |archivedate=2014 |isbn=}}</ref> Some Indian women in Guiana had multiple partners due to the greater number of men than woman, an account of the era told by women in British Guiana is of a single Chinese man who was allowed to temporarily borrow a Hindu Indian woman by her Indian husband who was his friend, so the Chinese man could sire a child with her, after a son was born to her the Chinese man kept the boy while she was returned to her Indian husband, the boy was named William Adrian Lee.<ref>{{cite book |page=119 |pages= |year=2013 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=Gaiutra Bahadur |quote= |location= |title=Coolie Woman: The Odyssey of Indenture |url=https://books.google.com/?id=iYBQAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA119&dq=Guiana+shortage+women+Indian+loaned+his+wife+to+the+Chinese+man. |isbn=0-226-04338-X}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=156 |pages= |year=1993 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=M. Kirkpatrick |volume=Volume 1 of From the Middle Kingdom to the New World |issn= |edition= |author=Margery Kirkpatrick |quote= |location= |title=From the Middle Kingdom to the New World: Aspects of the Chinese Experience in Migration to British Guiana, Volume 1 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=yVdLAAAAYAAJ&q=The+child+was+baptised+William+Adrian+and+was+brought+up+by+his+father.+His+mother+was+supposed+to+be+a+Hindu+with+two+sons,+Amna+and+Safia,+older+than+William,+and+was+called+Gang+Gang+by+William%27s+children.+A+younger+son,+Gulan+...&dq=The+child+was+baptised+William+Adrian+and+was+brought+up+by+his+father.+His+mother+was+supposed+to+be+a+Hindu+with+two+sons,+Amna+and+Safia,+older+than+William,+and+was+called+Gang+Gang+by+William%27s+children.+A+younger+son,+Gulan+... |isbn=976-8136-27-8}}</ref> An Indian woman named Mary See married a Chinese man surnamed Wu in Goedverwagting and founded their own family after he learned how to process sugar cane.<ref>{{cite book |page=128 |pages= |year=1993 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=M. Kirkpatrick |volume=Volume 1 of From the Middle Kingdom to the New World |issn= |edition= |author=Margery Kirkpatrick |quote= |location= |title=From the Middle Kingdom to the New World: Aspects of the Chinese Experience in Migration to British Guiana, Volume 1 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=yVdLAAAAYAAJ&q=Goedverwagting,+near+Ogle,+where+he+was+taught+the+secrets+of+%27pan-boiling%27+%E2%80%94+the+process+by+which+the+sugar+cane+juice+is+boiled+down+until+granulation+occurs.+At+Goedverwagting+he+took+an+East+Indian+wife,+Mary+See,+and+proceeded+to+produce+his+own+dynasty+%28see+family+Wu%29.+According+to+the+Register+of+Stillbirths,+death+1872-593,+U-A-KONG+was+born+dead+on+8th+September,+1872+to+U-A-HING&dq=Goedverwagting,+near+Ogle,+where+he+was+taught+the+secrets+of+%27pan-boiling%27+%E2%80%94+the+process+by+which+the+sugar+cane+juice+is+boiled+down+until+granulation+occurs.+At+Goedverwagting+he+took+an+East+Indian+wife,+Mary+See,+and+proceeded+to+produce+his+own+dynasty+%28see+family+Wu%29.+According+to+the+Register+of+Stillbirths,+death+1872-593,+U-A-KONG+was+born+dead+on+8th+September,+1872+to+U-A-HING |isbn=976-8136-27-8}}</ref> In British Guiana the Chinese did not maintain their distinctive physical features due to the high rate of Chinese men marrying people other ethnicities like Indian women.<ref>{{cite book |page=108 |pages= |year=1998 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=Times Academic Press |volume=Volume 2 of The Chinese Diaspora |issue= |issn= |edition=illustrated |editor=L. Liang-chi Wang |editor2=Gungwu Wang |quote= |location= |title=The Chinese Diaspora: Selected Essays, Volume 2 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=iC5xAAAAMAAJ&dq=Many%2C+particularly+the+men+who+outnumbered+the+women%2C+married+East+Indian%2C+Creole+and+Amerindian+women.+Today%2C+most+Guyanese+Chinese+families+include+members+of+all+shades+and+complexion+reflecting+these+diverse+origins.+Unlike+the+European&q=particularly+married+most+include |isbn=981-210-093-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=42 |edition=2 |pages= |year=1993 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=Federal Research Division, Library of Congress |volume=Volume 550 |issue=Issue 82 of Area handbook series |issn=1057-5294 |editor=Tim Merrill |others=Library of Congress. Federal Research Division |title=Guyana and Belize: Country Studies |url=https://books.google.com/?id=VnAsAAAAYAAJ&q=Because+almost+all+of+the+Chinese+indentured+immigrants+were+men,+they+tended+to+intermarry+with+both+East+Indians+and+Africans,+and+thus+the+Chinese+of+Guyana+did+not+remain+as+physically+distinct+as+other+groups.+Like+the+Portuguese,+the+...&dq=Because+almost+all+of+the+Chinese+indentured+immigrants+were+men,+they+tended+to+intermarry+with+both+East+Indians+and+Africans,+and+thus+the+Chinese+of+Guyana+did+not+remain+as+physically+distinct+as+other+groups.+Like+the+Portuguese,+the+... |isbn=0-8444-0778-X}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=48 |pages= |year=2000 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=University of Denver, CTIR |volume= |issue= |issn= |edition= |author1=Jenny Pettit |author2=Caroline Starbird |title=Contemporary Issues in South America |url=https://books.google.com/?id=t1Jr5Lymk_EC&pg=PA48&dq=many+Chinese+men+taken+to+Guyana+those+who+remained+tended+to+marry+East+Indians |isbn=0-943804-90-6}}</ref> The severe imbalance with Indian men outnumbering Indian women led some women to take advantage of the situation to squeeze favors from men and leave their partners for other men,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://flax.nzdl.org/greenstone3/flax;jsessionid=052401C6323F0CF2209B8A03DDD5FA55?a=d&c=BAWEAH&d=D2190&dt=simple&p.a=b&p.s=ClassifierBrowse |title=How much was immigrant culture affected by the realities of life in Guyana and the norms of other racial groups present in Guyana between 1838 and 1905? |date= |website=flax |publisher=British Academic Written English (Arts and Humanities) |accessdate= |quote=}}</ref> one infamous example was a pretty, light skinned, Christian Indian woman named Mary Ilandun with ancestral origins from [[Madras]], born in 1846, who had sex with Indian, black, and Chinese men as she married them in succession and ran off with their money to her next paramour, doing this from 1868 to 1884.<ref>{{cite book |pages=169–171 |year=1995 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=McGill-Queen's Press – MQUP |volume=Volume 22 of McGill-Queen's studies in ethnic history |issn=0846-8869 |edition=illustrated |author=Brian L. Moore |title=Cultural Power, Resistance, and Pluralism: Colonial Guyana, 1838–1900 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=cx_9-X_-smoC&pg=PA171&dq=Mary+Ilandun+men+purpose |isbn=0-7735-1354-X}}</ref> Indian men used force to bring Indian women back in line from this kind of behavior.<ref>{{cite book |page=9 |pages= |year=1989 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=University of Guyana, Department of History |volume= |issn= |edition= |others=University of Guyana. History Society, University of Guyana. Department of History |title=Guyana Historical Journal, Volumes 1-5 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=B9soAQAAMAAJ&q=mary+ilandun&dq=mary+ilandun |isbn=}}</ref> The most severe lack of women in all the peoples of British Guiana was with the Chinese and this led Europeans to believe that Chinese did not engage in wife murders while wife murders was something innate to Indian men, and unlike Indian coolie women, Chinese women were viewed as chaste.<ref>{{cite book |page=116 |pages= |year=2013 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=Gaiutra Bahadur |title=Coolie Woman: The Odyssey of Indenture |url=https://books.google.com/?id=iYBQAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA116&dq=chinese+men+married+indian+women+trinidad |isbn=0-226-04338-X}}</ref> Chinese women were not indentured and since they did not need to work, they avoided prospective men seeking relationships, while the character of Indian women was disparaged as immoral and their alleged sexual looseness was blamed for their deaths in the "wife murders" by Indian men.<ref>{{cite book |pages=117–118 |year=2013 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=Gaiutra Bahadur |quote= |location= |title=Coolie Woman: The Odyssey of Indenture |url=https://books.google.com/?id=iYBQAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA117&dq=walton+look+lie+carribean+chinese+indian+women |isbn=0-226-04338-X}}</ref> The sex ratio of Indian men to Indian women was 100:63 while the sex ratio of Chinese men to Chinese women was 100:43 in British Guiana in 1891.<ref>{{cite book |page=234 |pages= |year=2013 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=Gaiutra Bahadur |quote= |location= |title=Coolie Woman: The Odyssey of Indenture |url=https://books.google.com/?id=iYBQAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA234&dq=indian+coolie+woman+chinese+men |isbn=0-226-04338-X}}</ref>
In East Coast Berbice in an Adelphi estate a Madrasi woman was cohabiting with a Chinese man in 1871.<ref>{{cite book |page=210 |edition=illustrated |pages= |year=1993 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press |volume= |author=Walton Look Lai |quote= |location= |title=Indentured labor, Caribbean sugar: Chinese and Indian migrants to the British West Indies, 1838–1918 |series=Johns Hopkins studies in Atlantic history and culture |url=https://books.google.com/?id=QJCxAAAAIAAJ&q=illicit+intercourse+between+the+Chinese,+East+Indian+immigrants,+and+Black+women:+but+I+speak+of+the+immigrants+as+a+whole.67+The+1871+report+also+recorded+a+rare+instance+of+a+Chinese+man+living+on+Adelphi+estate+in+East+Coast+Berbice+with+a+Madrasi+woman.68+Gradually,+as+the+newcomers+acclimatized+to+their+new&dq=illicit+intercourse+between+the+Chinese,+East+Indian+immigrants,+and+Black+women:+but+I+speak+of+the+immigrants+as+a+whole.67+The+1871+report+also+recorded+a+rare+instance+of+a+Chinese+man+living+on+Adelphi+estate+in+East+Coast+Berbice+with+a+Madrasi+woman.68+Gradually,+as+the+newcomers+acclimatized+to+their+new |isbn=0-8018-4465-7}}</ref>
Over time, although there were more Creole marriages with Chinese, there was a growth of Indian marriages with Chinese and it was reported that "It is not an uncommon thing to find a cooly woman living with a Chinaman as his wife, and in one or two instances the woman has accompanied her reputed husband to China." by Dr. Comins in 1891, with six Indian women marrying Chinese men in 1892 as reported by The Immigration Report for 1892.<ref>{{cite book |page=210 |edition=illustrated |pages= |year=1993 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press |volume= |author=Walton Look Lai |quote= |location= |title=Indentured labor, Caribbean sugar: Chinese and Indian migrants to the British West Indies, 1838–1918 |series=Johns Hopkins studies in Atlantic history and culture |url=https://books.google.com/?id=QJCxAAAAIAAJ&q=and+to+one+another,+Chinese-Indian+unions+increased,+although+probably+more+slowly+than+Chinese-Creole+unions.+By+1891,+Dr.+Comins+was+saying,+%22It+is+not+an+uncommon+thing+to+find+a+cooly+woman+living+with+a+Chinaman+as+his+wife,+and+in+one+or+two+instances+the+woman+has+accompanied+her+reputed+husband+to+China.%2269+The+Immigration+Report+for+1892+reported+six+marriages+between+Chinese+men+and+Indian+women+in+British+Guiana.&dq=and+to+one+another,+Chinese-Indian+unions+increased,+although+probably+more+slowly+than+Chinese-Creole+unions.+By+1891,+Dr.+Comins+was+saying,+%22It+is+not+an+uncommon+thing+to+find+a+cooly+woman+living+with+a+Chinaman+as+his+wife,+and+in+one+or+two+instances+the+woman+has+accompanied+her+reputed+husband+to+China.%2269+The+Immigration+Report+for+1892+reported+six+marriages+between+Chinese+men+and+Indian+women+in+British+Guiana. |isbn=0-8018-4465-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=350 |pages= |year=1995 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=McGill-Queen's Press – MQUP |volume=Volume 22 of McGill-Queen's studies in ethnic history |issn=0846-8869 |edition=illustrated |author=Brian L. Moore |title=Cultural Power, Resistance, and Pluralism: Colonial Guyana, 1838–1900 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=cx_9-X_-smoC&pg=PA350&dq=The+Immigration+Report+for+1892+reported+six+marriages+between+Chinese+men+and+Indian+women+i |isbn=0-7735-1354-X}}</ref>
=== Trinidad === In Trinidad some [[Chinese Trinidadian and Tobagonian|Chinese men]] had sexual relations [[Indo-Trinidadian and Tobagonian|Indian coolie women]], siring children with them, and it was reported that "A few children are to be met with born of Madras and Creole parents and some also of Madras and Chinese parents – the Madrasee being the mother", by the missionary John Morton in 1876, Morton noted that it seemed strange since there were more Indian coolie men than Indian coolie women that Indian coolie women would marry Chinese men, but claimed it was most likely because the Chinese could provide amenities to the women since the Chinese owned shops and they were enticed by these.<ref>{{cite book |page=14 |pages= |year=2014 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing |volume= |issn= |edition= |editor=Julitta Rydlewska |editor2=Barbara Braid |title=Unity in Diversity, Volume 1: Cultural Paradigm and Personal Identity, Volume 1 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=WBVQBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA14&dq=some+also+of+madras+and+chinese+parents+the+madrasee+being+the+mother |archiveurl=http://www.cambridgescholars.com/download/sample/61376 |archivedate=2014 |isbn=1-4438-6729-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=238 |pages= |year=1995 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Nycan |edition= |author=Dennison Moore |quote= |location= |title=Origins and Development of Racial Ideology in Trinidad |url=https://books.google.com/?id=kTV7AAAAMAAJ&dq=some+also+of+madras+and+chinese+parents+the+madrasee+being+the+mother&q=being+mother |isbn=0-9680060-0-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=263 |pages= |year=1999 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Sir Arthur Lewis Institute of Social and Economic Studies, The University of the West Indies |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=Selwyn D. Ryan |quote= |location= |title=The Jhandi and the Cross: The Clash of Cultures in Post-creole Trinidad and Tobago |url=https://books.google.com/?id=lDVsAAAAMAAJ&dq=some+also+of+madras+and+chinese+parents+the+madrasee+being+the+mother&q=being+mother+coolie |isbn=976-618-031-8}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |pages=65–66 |year=2014 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=NYU Press |editor=Rebecca Chiyoko King-O'Riain |editor2=Stephen Small |editor3=Minelle Mahtani |quote= |location= |title=Global Mixed Race |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a0bbAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA65 |archiveurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=SszaAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT80&dq=some+also+of+madras+and+chinese+parents+the+madrasee+being+the+mother&hl=en |archivedate=2014 |isbn=0-8147-7047-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Regis |first=Ferne Louanne |date=April 2011 |title=The Dougla in Trinidad's Consciousness |url=http://uwispace.sta.uwi.edu/dspace/bitstream/handle/2139/11131/Article%201%20-%20regis.pdf?sequence=1 |archiveurl=http://www.mainlib.uwi.tt/epubs/historyaction/papers/printversion2.pdf |archivedate=8 Mar 2011 |journal=History in Action |publisher=The University of the West Indies (St. Augustine, Trinidad and Tobago) Dept. of History |volume=2 |issue=1 |issn=2221-7886 |pages= |doi= |accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref> Indian women were married by indentured Chinese men in Trinidad.<ref>{{cite book |page=315 |pages= |year=2013 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Coach House Books |volume= |issn= |edition=illustrated |author=Mike Hoolboom |editor=Mike Hoolboom |quote= |location= |title=Practical Dreamers: Conversations with Movie Artists |series= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=n8eOKiK3llYC&pg=PA315&dq=chinese+men+married+indian+women+trinidad |isbn=1-77056-181-1}}</ref> Few Chinese women migrated to Trinidad while the majority of Chinese migrants were men.<ref>{{cite book |page=54 |pages= |year=2014 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=NYU Press |volume= |issn= |edition= |editor=Rebecca Chiyoko King-O'Riain |editor2=Stephen Small |editor3=Minelle Mahtani |quote= |location= |title=Global Mixed Race |url=https://books.google.com/?id=a0bbAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA54&dq=chinese+men+married+indian+women+trinidad |isbn=0-8147-7047-9}}</ref> The migration of Chinese to Trinidad resulted in intermarriage between them and others.<ref>{{cite book |page=26 |pages= |year=1992 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Inprint Caribbean |volume= |issn= |edition=2 |author=Adrian Curtis Bird |quote= |location= |title=Trinidad sweet: the people, their culture, their island |url=https://books.google.com/?id=uVMYAAAAYAAJ&q=They+intermarried+more+readily+into+other+ethnic+groups+and+produced+many+of+the+most+exotically+glamorous+results.+...+British+Guiana+moved+more+quickly+and+brought+over+20,000+Portuguese+into+their+territory.&dq=They+intermarried+more+readily+into+other+ethnic+groups+and+produced+many+of+the+most+exotically+glamorous+results.+...+British+Guiana+moved+more+quickly+and+brought+over+20,000+Portuguese+into+their+territory. |isbn=0-8147-7047-9}}</ref> Chinese in Trinidad became relatively open to having marital relations with other races and Indian women began having families with Chinese in the 1890s.<ref>{{cite book |page=95 |pages= |year=2000 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Kaisa Para Sa Kaunlaran, Incorporated |volume= |issn= |edition=2 |editor=Teresita Ang See |others=International Society for the Studies of Chinese Overseas, Kaisa Para Sa Kaunlaran |quote= |location= |title=Intercultural Relations, Cultural Transformation, and Identity: The Ethnic Chinese : Selected Papers Presented at the 1998 ISSCO Conference |url=https://books.google.com/?id=-VhwAAAAMAAJ&q=In+comparison+with+the+South+Asian+Indians,+the+Chinese+attitudes+toward+interracial+marriages+or+unions+were+far+less+racially+exclusive+and+devoid+of+many+of+the+caste+taboos+of+the+Indians.+By+the+1+890s,+there+was+already+a+sizeable+mixed+Chinese+community.+As+in+Southeast+Asia,+many+Chinese+started+second+families+overseas+with+local+women,+some+of+whom+were+South+Asian+Indians,+as+well+as+with+Creole+women.&dq=In+comparison+with+the+South+Asian+Indians,+the+Chinese+attitudes+toward+interracial+marriages+or+unions+were+far+less+racially+exclusive+and+devoid+of+many+of+the+caste+taboos+of+the+Indians.+By+the+1+890s,+there+was+already+a+sizeable+mixed+Chinese+community.+As+in+Southeast+Asia,+many+Chinese+started+second+families+overseas+with+local+women,+some+of+whom+were+South+Asian+Indians,+as+well+as+with+Creole+women. |isbn=971-8857-21-4}}</ref>
The situation in Trinidad and British Guiana with Indian women being fewer than Indian men led to Indian women using the situation to their advantage by leaving their partners for other men, leading to a high incidence of "wife murders" by Indian men on their wives, and Indian women and culture were branded as "immoral" by European observers, an Indian man named Mohammad Orfy petitioned as a representative of "destitute Indian men of Trinidad", to the colonial authorities, complaining of Indian women's behavior and claiming that it was "a perforating plague.....the high percentage of immoral lives led by the female section of our community......to satisfy the greed and lust of the male section of quite a different race to theirs........[Indian women] are enticed, seduced and frightened into becoming concubines, and paramours....... [Indian women] have absolutely no knowledge whatsoever of the value of being in virginhood......most shameless and a perfect menace to the Indian gentry." with him naming specific peoples, claiming that Indian women were having sex with Chinese men, Americans, Africans, and Europeans,<ref>{{cite book |pages=263–264 |year=2001 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Duke University Press |volume=Volume 1 of A millennial quartet book, Volume 11 of Public culture |issn= |edition=illustrated |author=Dilip Parameshwar Gaonkar |editor=Dilip Parameshwar Gaonkar |quote= |location= |title=Alternative Modernities |url=https://books.google.com/?id=YCghDtjik3IC&pg=PA263&dq=chinese+men+married+indian+women+trinidad |isbn=0-8223-2714-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=135 |pages= |year=2000 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Zed Books |volume= |issn= |edition=illustrated, reprint |author1=Janaki Nair |author2=Mary E. John |editor1=Janaki Nair |editor2=Mary E. John |others= |quote= |location= |title=A Question of Silence: The Sexual Economies of Modern India |url=https://books.google.com/?id=gUJ6112aGZQC&pg=PA135&dq=chinese+men+married+indian+women+trinidad |isbn=1-85649-892-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=24 |pages= |year=1997 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=University of Natal, History and African Studies Seminar |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=University of Natal |others= |quote= |location= |title=History and African Studies Seminar series, Issues 1-25 |series=History and African Studies Seminar Series, University of Natal |url=https://books.google.com/?id=OKcvAQAAIAAJ&q=Africans,+Americans+and+Chinese%22%5D,+Indian+women+%22are+enticed,+seduced+and+frightened+into+becoming+concubines,+and+paramours%22.&dq=Africans,+Americans+and+Chinese%22%5D,+Indian+women+%22are+enticed,+seduced+and+frightened+into+becoming+concubines,+and+paramours%22. |isbn=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=44 |pages= |year=1998 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Bloomsbury Academic |volume=Volume 18 of Cross-Cultural Perspectives on Women |issn= |edition=illustrated |editor1=Shobita Jain |editor2=Rhoda E. Reddock |title=Women Plantation Workers: International Experiences |series= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=vPMEAQAAIAAJ&q=Africans,+Americans+and+Chinese%22%5D,+Indian+women+%22are+enticed,+seduced+and+frightened+into+becoming+concubines,+and+paramours%22.&dq=Africans,+Americans+and+Chinese%22%5D,+Indian+women+%22are+enticed,+seduced+and+frightened+into+becoming+concubines,+and+paramours%22. |isbn=1-85973-972-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=322 |pages= |year=2001 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Ian Randle |volume=Volume 18 of Cross-Cultural Perspectives on Women |issn= |edition=illustrated |author1=Rhoda Reddock |author2=Christine Barrow |editor1=Rhoda Reddock |editor2=Christine Barrow |others= |quote= |location= |title=Caribbean sociology: introductory readings |series= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=YN4SAQAAMAAJ&q=Africans,+Americans+and+Chinese%22%5D,+Indian+women+%22are+enticed,+seduced+and+frightened+into+becoming+concubines,+and+paramours%22.&dq=Africans,+Americans+and+Chinese%22%5D,+Indian+women+%22are+enticed,+seduced+and+frightened+into+becoming+concubines,+and+paramours%22. |isbn=1-55876-276-0}}</ref> saying "Africans, Americans and Chinese in goodly numbers are enticing the females of India, who are more or less subtle to lustful traps augured through some fear of punishment being meted out if not readily submissive as requested."<ref>{{cite book |page=44 |pages= |year=1998 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Bloomsbury Academic |volume=Volume 18 of Cross-Cultural Perspectives on Women |issn= |edition=illustrated |editor1=Shobita Jain |editor2=Rhoda E. Reddock |others= |quote= |location= |title=Women Plantation Workers: International Experiences |series= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=vPMEAQAAIAAJ&q=Africans,+Americans+and+Chinese+in+goodly+numbers+are+enticing+the+females+of+India,+who+are+more+or+less+subtle+to+lustful+traps&dq=Africans,+Americans+and+Chinese+in+goodly+numbers+are+enticing+the+females+of+India,+who+are+more+or+less+subtle+to+lustful+traps |isbn=1-85973-972-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=101 |pages= |year=1988 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=CUNY Association of Caribbean Studies |volume=Volume 18 of Cross-Cultural Perspectives on Women |issn= |edition=illustrated |others=City University of New York.
