E. Reddock |volume= |issn= |edition=illustrated |author=Rhoda Reddock |quote= |location= |title=Women, labour and struggle in 20th century Trinidad and Tobago, 1898–1960 |series= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=kWy2AAAAIAAJ&q=Africans,+Americans+and+Chinese+in+goodly+numbers+are+enticing+the+females+of+India,+who+are+more+or+less+subtle+to+lustful+traps&dq=Africans,+Americans+and+Chinese+in+goodly+numbers+are+enticing+the+females+of+India,+who+are+more+or+less+subtle+to+lustful+traps |isbn=}}</ref>
The situation on Trinidad enabled unprecedented autonomy in the sexual activities of Indian women and freedom.<ref name="auto1">{{cite journal |last=Reddock |first=Rhoda |date=26 October 1985 |title=Freedom Denied: Indian Women and Indentureship in Trinidad and Tobago, 1845–1917 |journal=Economic and Political Weekly |publisher= |volume=20 |issue=43 |page=WS-84 |jstor=4374974 |doi=}}</ref> The 1916 "Peition of Indentured Labourers in Trinidad" complained that: "Is it permissible for a male member of the Christian faith to keep a Hindoo or Muslim female as his paramour or concubine? Is this not an act of sacrilege and a disgraceful scandal according to the Christian faith to entice and encourage Indian females to lead immoral lives?"<ref name="auto1"/>
Indian men used violence against Indian women in response to Indian women engaging in sexual relations with multiple men due to the shortage of them in Trinidad.<ref>{{cite book |page=156 |pages= |year=2010 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=Donette Francis |quote= |location= |title=Fictions of Feminine Citizenship: Sexuality and the Nation in Contemporary Caribbean Literature |series= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=gcHHAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA156&dq=walton+look+lai+caribbean+chinese+indian+women |isbn=0-230-10577-7}}</ref>
On plantations white European managers took advantage of and use indentured Indian woman for sex,<ref>{{cite book |page=53 |pages= |year=2014 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=NYU Press |volume= |issn= |edition= |editor=Rebecca Chiyoko King-O'Riain |editor2=Stephen Small |editor3=Minelle Mahtani |quote= |location= |title=Global Mixed Race |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a0bbAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA53 |isbn=0-8147-7047-9}}</ref> in addition, English, Portuguese, and Chinese men were also in sexual relationships with Indian women as noted by Attorney General W.F. Haynes Smith, while Creole women were abhorred or ignored by Indian men.<ref>{{cite book |page=37 |pages= |year=2005 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=University Press of America |volume= |issn= |edition=illustrated |author=Basdeo Mangru |title=The Elusive El Dorado: Essays on the Indian Experience in Guyana |series= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=DOhrAAAAMAAJ&q=but+also+cited+cases+of+Indian+women+cohabiting+with+the+Chinese,+Portuguese+and+Englishmen.26+In+1897+J.E.+Tinne,&dq=but+also+cited+cases+of+Indian+women+cohabiting+with+the+Chinese,+Portuguese+and+Englishmen.26+In+1897+J.E.+Tinne, |isbn=0-7618-3247-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=216 |pages= |year=1987 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Hansib |volume= |issn= |edition=illustrated |editor1=David Dabydeen |editor2=Brinsley Samaroo |others=David Dabydeen |quote= |location= |title=India in the Caribbean |series=Hansib / University of Warwick, Centre for Caribbean Studies publication |url=https://books.google.com/?id=X_AMAQAAMAAJ&q=but+also+cited+cases+of+Indian+women+cohabiting+with+the+Chinese,+Portuguese+and+Englishmen.26+In+1897+J.E.+Tinne,&dq=but+also+cited+cases+of+Indian+women+cohabiting+with+the+Chinese,+Portuguese+and+Englishmen.26+In+1897+J.E.+Tinne, |isbn=1-870518-05-5}}</ref> Approval of interracial marriage has slowly increased in Trinidad and Tobago and one Chinese man reported that his Indian wife did not encounter any rejection from his parents when asked in a survey.<ref>{{cite book |page=65 |pages= |year=2003 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=SAGE Publications |volume= |issn= |edition=illustrated |editor1=Raeann R Hamon |editor2=Bron B Ingoldsby |others=David Dabydeen |quote= |location= |title=Mate Selection Across Cultures |series= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=cPCeb2CGJ3kC&pg=PA65&dq=chinese+men+married+indian+women+trinidad |isbn=1-4522-3769-7}}</ref> In Trinidad Europeans and Chinese are seen as acceptable marriage partners by Indians while marrying black men would lead to rejection of their daughters by Indian families.<ref>{{cite book |page=107 |pages= |year=2010 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |volume= |issn= |edition=illustrated |author1=Colin Clarke |author2=Gillian Clarke |title=Post-Colonial Trinidad: An Ethnographic Journal |series=Studies of the Americas |url=https://books.google.com/?id=3brHAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA107&dq=chinese+men+married+indian+women+trinidad |isbn=0-230-10685-4}}</ref>
In British Guiana and Trinidad, white overseers and managers would take advantage of Indian coolie women and use them in sexual relationships, the Indian women were then blamed for these incidents and viewed as allegedly "loose" and promiscuous by colonial officials, and Indian women were subjected to a high rate of "wife murders" by Indian men, the Indian women were also blamed for this due to their "inconstancy" due to alleged low "sexual morality".<ref>{{cite book |page=110 |edition=illustrated |pages= |year=2011 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=University of Virginia Press |volume= |author=Tejaswini Niranjana |editor=Faith L. Smith |quote= |location= |title=Sex and the Citizen: Interrogating the Caribbean |series=New World Studies |url=https://books.google.com/?id=yi2SIDGBfvMC&pg=PA110&dq=estate+manager+indian+women+seven+caribbean |isbn=0-8139-3132-0}}</ref>
In one incident in Trinidad, seven Indian women were impregnated at the same time by an estate manager in 1854.<ref>{{cite book |page=144 |edition=illustrated |pages= |year=1993 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press |volume= |author=Walton Look Lai |quote= |location= |title=Indentured labor, Caribbean sugar: Chinese and Indian migrants to the British West Indies, 1838–1918 |series=Johns Hopkins studies in Atlantic history and culture |url=https://books.google.com/?id=QJCxAAAAIAAJ&q=walton+look+lai+caribbean+chinese+indian+women&dq=walton+look+lai+caribbean+chinese+indian+women |isbn=0-8018-4465-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=343 |edition= |pages= |year=1999 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=Marcus Wiener |volume= |author=Christine Barrow |quote= |location= |title=Family in the Caribbean: themes and perspectives |series= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=GENHAAAAYAAJ&q=estate+manager+indian+women+seven+caribbean&dq=estate+manager+indian+women+seven+caribbean |isbn=1-55876-207-8}}</ref>
The managers sexual relations with Indian women caused riots, at the most significant one, at the hands of the police, 59 Indians were wounded and 5 Indians were killed, in Non Pareil in 1896, due to an Indian woman cohabiting with Gerad Van Nooten, the acting manager.<ref>{{cite book |page=125 |pages= |year=1987 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Hansib |volume= |issn= |edition=illustrated |editor1=David Dabydeen |editor2=Brinsley Samaroo |others=David Dabydeen |title=India in the Caribbean |series=Hansib / University of Warwick, Centre for Caribbean Studies publication |url=https://books.google.com/?id=X_AMAQAAMAAJ&q=Evidence+later+disclosed+that+the+acting+manager,+Van+Nooten,+had+been+living+with+an+Indian+woman+and+the+attorney+of+the+estate+not+only+declined+to+take+any+action+but+endeavoured+to+protect+him.+Various+measures+adopted+by+the&dq=Evidence+later+disclosed+that+the+acting+manager,+Van+Nooten,+had+been+living+with+an+Indian+woman+and+the+attorney+of+the+estate+not+only+declined+to+take+any+action+but+endeavoured+to+protect+him.+Various+measures+adopted+by+the |isbn=1-870518-05-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Pillai |first=Suresh Kumar |date=2004 |title=NDENTURED INDIANS Emergence of Hindu identity in Carrbian Countries |url=https://www.academia.edu/447217/INDENTURED_INDIANS |journal= |publisher= |volume= |issue= |page=29 |doi= |accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Pillai |first=Suresh Kumar |date= |title=THE SILENCED MAJORITY: INDIAN CULTURE AND RACIAL CONFLICT IN GUYANA |url=https://www.academia.edu/414243/SILENCED_MAJORITY |journal= |publisher= |volume= |issue= |page=37 |doi=|access-date=28 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Mahabir |first=Kumar |date=May–June 2004 |title=Indian Arrival Day |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/249438765/Indian-Arrival-2004#scribd |journal= |publisher=Indo-Caribbean Cultural Council |volume=5 |issue=1 |location=Trinidad & Tobago |page=52 |doi=|access-date=28 June 2015}}</ref>
The low ratio of Indian women compared to Indian men, along with the factor of Portuguese, white overseers and managers, and Chinese men having sexual relations with Indian women, aggravated the problem of rivalry for Indian women between Indian men, and drove up the value of Indian women.<ref>{{cite book |page=72 |pages= |year=2000 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=NYU Press |volume= |issn= |edition=illustrated |author=Ron Ramdin |quote= |location= |title=Arising from Bondage: A History of the Indo-Caribbean People |url=https://books.google.com/?id=9wb4Q-By4SsC&pg=PA72&dq=estate+manager+indian+women+seven+caribbean |isbn=0-8147-7548-9}}</ref>
The incidents of overseers and managers taking sexual advantage of the women laborers led to Indian laborers causing stoppages and protests.<ref>{{cite book |page=239 |pages= |year=2012 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |volume= |issn= |edition=illustrated |author=Martin Thomas |title=Violence and Colonial Order: Police, Workers and Protest in the European Colonial Empires, 1918–1940 |series=Critical Perspectives on Empire |url=https://books.google.com/?id=F2sb31VZdSkC&pg=PA239&dq=estate+manager+indian+women+seven+caribbean |isbn=0-521-76841-1}}</ref> In British Guiana the overseers and managers sexual abuse of Indian women caused Indian workers to embark on a "struggle" from 1869–1872.<ref>{{cite book |page=78 |pages= |year=2002 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Beacon Press |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=Vijay Prashad |title=Everybody Was Kung Fu Fighting: Afro-Asian Connections and the Myth of Cultural Purity |series=Critical Perspectives on Empire |url=https://books.google.com/?id=xiO6zUS9gigC&pg=PA175&dq=walton+look+lai+caribbean+chinese+indian+women |isbn=0-8070-5011-3}}</ref> Conflicts due to women led to attacks against drivers and overseers.<ref>{{cite book |page=142 |edition=illustrated |pages= |year=1993 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press |volume= |author=Walton Look Lai |title=Indentured labor, Caribbean sugar: Chinese and Indian migrants to the British West Indies, 1838–1918 |series=Johns Hopkins studies in Atlantic history and culture |url=https://books.google.com/?id=QJCxAAAAIAAJ&dq=walton+look+lai+trinidad+indian+women&q=indian+women |isbn=0-8018-4465-7}}</ref> The resentment of the workers was aggravated by the use of women on estates for sexual relations.<ref>{{cite book |page=143 |edition=illustrated |pages= |year=1993 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press |volume= |author=Walton Look Lai |quote= |location= |title=Indentured labor, Caribbean sugar: Chinese and Indian migrants to the British West Indies, 1838–1918 |series=Johns Hopkins studies in Atlantic history and culture |url=https://books.google.com/?id=QJCxAAAAIAAJ&q=estate+manager+indian+women+seven+caribbean&dq=estate+manager+indian+women+seven+caribbean |isbn=0-8018-4465-7}}</ref>
The deficit in Indian women compared to men was caused by the recruitment quota ratio of 100 men to 40 women, most of the women were young and single,<ref>{{cite journal |last=Pillai |first=Suresh Kumar |date= |title=THE SILENCED MAJORITY: INDIAN CULTURE AND RACIAL CONFLICT IN GUYANA |url=https://www.academia.edu/414243/SILENCED_MAJORITY |journal= |publisher= |volume= |issue= |page=16 |doi= |accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref> and the shortage of Indian women for Indian men was aggravated when Indian women were taken by Africans and European overseers, leading to high amounts of wife murders against Indian women by Indian men and a decrease in morals.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Pillai |first=Suresh Kumar |date=2004 |title=NDENTURED INDIANS Emergence of Hindu identity in Carrbian Countries |url=https://www.academia.edu/447217/INDENTURED_INDIANS |journal= |publisher= |volume= |issue= |page=15 |doi= |accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref> The appropriation of Indian women by Europeans and Africans added up to the resentment which contributed to violence against Indian women by Indian men.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Pillai |first=Suresh Kumar |date= |title=THE SILENCED MAJORITY: INDIAN CULTURE AND RACIAL CONFLICT IN GUYANA |url=https://www.academia.edu/414243/SILENCED_MAJORITY |journal= |publisher= |volume= |issue= |pages=22–23 |doi= |accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref> Indian women on plantations took part in the struggle against Africans and European authorities who were sexually using them.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Pillai |first=Suresh Kumar |date= |title=THE SILENCED MAJORITY: INDIAN CULTURE AND RACIAL CONFLICT IN GUYANA |url=https://www.academia.edu/414243/SILENCED_MAJORITY |journal= |publisher= |volume= |issue= |page=26 |doi= |accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Mahabir |first=Kumar |date=May–June 2004 |title=Indian Arrival Day |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/249438765/Indian-Arrival-2004#scribd |journal= |publisher=Indo-Caribbean Cultural Council |volume=5 |issue=1 |location=Trinidad & Tobago |page=18 |doi= |accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref>
Indian nationalists ashamed of the sexual reputation of Indian coolie women often attacked the coolie trade for that reason instead of other reasons such as bad working conditions.<ref name="aaww.org">{{cite web |url=http://aaww.org/coolie-womans-work-gaiutra-bahadur/ |title=A Coolie Woman’s Work is Never Done |last1=Paul |first1=Annie |date=31 March 2014 |website=ASIAN AMERICAN WRITERS' WORKSHOP |publisher= |accessdate=28 June 2015 |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160504160529/http://aaww.org/coolie-womans-work-gaiutra-bahadur/ |archivedate=4 May 2016 |df=dmy}}</ref> Overseers and planters on the plantations and sailors and doctors on board the ships transporting Indian coolie women would try to obtain sex from Indian women.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://socialistaction.org/book-review-coolie-woman/ |title=Book review: ‘Coolie Woman’ |last1=MARIE |first1=CHRISTINE |date=9 March 2014 |website=socialistaction |publisher= |accessdate=28 June 2015 |quote=}}</ref>
The Indian women had a sexual bargaining chip since they could frequently change lovers due to the fact that there were less Indian women than men, The Daily Chronicle described Indian coolie women as "pretty and youthful", laborers had to be moved around plantations by managers to prevent men from killing their adulterous wives, and the aura surrounding the sexuality and perils of Indian coolie women was enhanced by the widespread worship of the goddess [[Kali]] by them.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.caravanmagazine.in/reporting-and-essays/her-middle-passage |title=Her Middle Passage |last1=BAHADUR |first1=GAIUTRA |date=1 September 2011 |website=The Caravan |publisher= |accessdate=28 June 2015 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vqronline.org/essay/coolie-women-are-demand-here |title=Coolie Women Are in Demand Here |last1=BAHADUR |first1=GAIUTRA |date=Spring 2011 |website=VQR |publisher= |accessdate=28 June 2015 |quote=}}</ref>
Riots and murders were blamed on the sexual liaisons between white overseers, managers and Indian coolie women in addition to their constant changing of sexual partners and the sexuality of coolie women were viewed shamefully as a deviation of the expected behavior of Indian women.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cimamag.com/coolie-woman-behind-the-c-word/ |title=‘COOLIE WOMAN': BEHIND THE ‘C’ WORD |last1=BABU |first1=CHAYA |date=January 2014 |website=CIMA |publisher=|access-date=28 June 2015 |quote=}}</ref>
The Guyanese-Indian journalist Gaiutra Bahadur wrote about the experiences of Indian coolie women.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://southasianlitfest.com/event/coolie-woman-the-odyssey-of-indenture-2/ |title=Coolie Woman THE ODYSSEY OF INDENTURE |date= |website=THE UNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO PRESS BOOKS |publisher=|access-date=28 June 2015 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://niemanreports.org/articles/writing-a-life-living-a-writers-life/ |title=Writing a Life, Living a Writer’s Life |last1=BAHADUR |first1=GAIUTRA |date=6 Dec 2011 |website=NiemanReports |publisher=|access-date=28 June 2015 |quote=}}</ref> Sex was utilized as a potent instrument by Indian coolie women such as when they obtained favors from overseers by having sex with them,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/C/bo13393932.html |title=Coolie Woman: The Odyssey of Indenture |date= |website=SOUTH ASIAN LITERATURE FESTIVAL |publisher=|access-date=28 June 2015 |quote=}}</ref> and the women could either have been "imperiled" or "empowered" when forming sexual relations with overseers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://repeatingislands.com/2014/03/30/gaiutra-bahadurs-coolie-woman-longlisted-for-the-orwell-prize/ |title=Gaiutra Bahadur’s "Coolie Woman" Longlisted for the Orwell Prize |author=ivetteromero |date=30 March 2014 |website=Repeating Islands |publisher=|access-date= 28 June 2015 |quote=}}</ref>
The Indian coolie women both had sexual advantages due to being less in number and suffered from sexual exploitation, in total, around 250,000 Indian women migrated as coolies.<ref>{{cite news |last=BEARAK |first=MAX |date=21 November 2013 <!-- 1:25 AM --> |title=A Conversation With: Author Gaiutra Bahadur |url=http://india.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/11/21/a-conversation-with-author-gaiutra-bahadur/?_r=0 |newspaper=New York Times |location=|access-date=28 June 2015}}</ref>
Gaiutra Bahadur said in an interview that some Guyanese from her community were angered by her book and writing on the sexual experiences of the Indian coolie woman, with one saying "Who is that woman who’s been writing that all of our grandmothers and great-grandmothers were prostitutes?", and another saying "One must be careful." to her, viewing her book as an attack on the honor and morals of Indian women, Bahadur maintained that she was trying to bring back the "dignity" of the women and that Indian women's honor was attacked in the same way by colonial officials who blamed the women themselves for their sexual liaisons rather than flaws in the plantation and indenture systems.<ref>{{cite news |author=Lauren K. Alleyne interviews Gaiutra Bahadur |date=17 November 2014 |title=Salvaged Crossings |url=https://www.guernicamag.com/interviews/salvaged-crossings/ |newspaper=GUERNICA |location=|access-date=28 June 2015}}</ref>
A stereotype of an uncontrollable sexual libido was attributed to Indian women in the Caribbean and they were described as having "white liver" because of this.<ref name="aaww.org" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.antiquusmorbus.com/English/Undefined.htm |title=Undefined Terms |date= |website=A Glossary of Archaic Medical Terms, Diseases and Causes of Death |publisher=|access-date= 28 June 2015 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://health-treatment.com/white-liver-disease-white-spots-liver/ |title=White liver disease- white spots on liver |author=health121 |date=14 September 2014 |website=Health-Treatment.Com |publisher=|access-date=28 June 2015 |quote=}}</ref>
Sexual abuse, horrible living standards, and tough work were all things Indian coolie women had to contend with.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://theaerogram.com/excerpt-gaiutra-bahadurs-coolie-woman-odyssey-indenture/ |title=An Excerpt From Gaiutra Bahadur’s ‘Coolie Woman: The Odyssey of Indenture’ |last1=Bahadur |first1=Gaiutra |date=11 April 2014 |website=The Aerogram |publisher=|access-date= 28 June 2015 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=ALI |first=GRACE ANEIZA |date=Spring 2014 |title=Gaiutra Bahadur Charts the ‘Coolie’ Woman’s Odyssey |url=http://www.ofnotemagazine.org/2014/04/30/guyanaindia/ |newspaper=OF NOTE magazine |location=|access-date=28 June 2015}}</ref>
In seeking potential mates the Indian coolie women has some amount of free choice due to their scarce numbers, some of them were able to end their indenture when married by white overseers.<ref>{{cite news |last=Roy |first=Sandip |date=14 Jun 2014 <!-- 11:18 IST --> |title=A woman alone: The story of India's forgotten 'coolie' women |url=http://www.firstpost.com/living/a-woman-alone-the-story-of-indias-forgotten-coolie-women-1569225.html |newspaper=Firstpost |location=|access-date=28 June 2015}}</ref>
There were cases of sexual abuse of Indian women on the ships and one man prostituted his 8-year-old daughter,<ref>{{cite book |page=67 |year=2013 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |edition= |author=Gaiutra Bahadur |title=Coolie Woman: The Odyssey of Indenture |url=https://books.google.com/?id=iYBQAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA67&dq=Another+sailor+saw+Balmer+descend+from+his+bunk+with+the+girl+at+11:10+p.m.,+take+her+to+a+biscuit+box+and+then+send+her+back+out+on+deck.+...+She+was+seven+or+eight+years+old.+Saroda%E2%80%94that+was+her+name%E2%80%94wasn%27t+travelling+with+a+mother.+She+was+supposed+to+stay+with+the+%22single%22+women+at+night,+but+often+slipped+through+the+mid-section+reserved+for+married+couples+to+the+front+of |isbn=0-226-04338-X}}</ref> and in another case a British surgeon married a young widow,<ref>{{cite book |page=72 |year=2013 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |volume= |edition= |author=Gaiutra Bahadur |title=Coolie Woman: The Odyssey of Indenture |url=https://books.google.com/?id=iYBQAQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=jamaica+indian+women+marry+chinese+men |isbn=0-226-04338-X}}</ref> the women obtained an advantage in sexual relations from being less numerous than men but this led to a large amount of killings called "wife murders" of the women by men they rejected.<ref>{{cite news |last=Wajid |first=Sara |date=19 November 2013 <!-- 03.00 EST --> |title=Journey of the 'coolie' women in the history of the British empire |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/womens-blog/2013/nov/19/journey-coolie-women-history-british-empire-indentured-labourers |newspaper=The Guardian |location=|access-date=28 June 2015}}</ref>
Postcards were made of Indian coolie women and girls bedecked in jewelry made of gold and silver such as [[bangle]]s and [[nose piercing|nose rings]] which seemed to be aiming to show them as wealthy and pretty.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://repeatingislands.com/2015/06/05/postcards-from-empire-by-gaiutra-bahadur/ |title=Postcards from Empire |last1=Bahadur |first1=Gaiutra |date=5 June 2015 |website=Repeating Islands |publisher=|access-date=28 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dissentmagazine.org/article/postcards-from-empire |title=Postcards from Empire |last1=Bahadur |first1=Gaiutra |date=Spring 2015 |newspaper=Dissent |publisher=|access-date=28 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=82 |year=2007 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=Duke University Press |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=Krista A. Thompson |others=Nicholas Thomas |title=An Eye for the Tropics: Tourism, Photography, and Framing the Caribbean Picturesque |url=https://books.google.com/?id=mWI8qR07eEEC&pg=PA82&dq=coolies+bangles |isbn=0-8223-8856-1}}</ref>
Indian coolie women wore their wealth in the form of jewellery,<ref>{{cite book |page=132 |edition= |pages= |year=2003 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=Routledge |volume= |author=Mimi Sheller |quote= |location= |title=Consuming the Caribbean: From Arawaks to Zombies |series=International Library of Sociology |url=https://books.google.com/?id=OY2BAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA132&dq=jewellery+wealth+coolie |isbn=1-134-51678-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=58 |edition= |pages= |year=1999 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=University of the West Indies Press |volume=Volume 4 of Press UWI biography series, Volume 4 of The @Press UWI biography series: University of the West Indies |author=Clem Seecharan |title=Bechu: 'bound Coolie' Radical in British Guiana, 1894–1901 |series= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=mDtFBvfuChYC&pg=PA58&dq=jewellery+wealth+coolie |isbn=976-640-071-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=40 |edition= |pages= |year=2008 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=Wildside Press LLC |volume= |author=Lafcadio Hearn |title=The Life and Letters of Lafcadio Hearn Including the Japanese Letters, Volume 2 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=qZxJPZnmsJ4C&pg=PA40&dq=jewellery+wealth+coolie |isbn=1-4344-9855-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=38 |pages= |year=2013 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=Gaiutra Bahadur |title=Coolie Woman: The Odyssey of Indenture |url=https://books.google.com/?id=iYBQAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA38&dq=jewellery+wealth+coolie |isbn=0-226-04338-X}}</ref> like [[bangle]]s and [[nose piercing|nose rings]].<ref>{{cite book |page=106 |pages= |year=1894 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=Macmillan and Company |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=Marianne North |editor=Janet Catherine North Symonds ("Mrs. J. A. Symonds, ") |title=Recollections of a Happy Life: Being the Autobiography of Marianne North, Volume 1 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=fdnVAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA106&dq=coolies+nose+rings |isbn=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=569 |pages= |year=1893 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=H. C. Maclean Publications |volume= |issn= |edition= |title=The Canadian Magazine, Volume 1 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=7QHOAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA569&dq=coolies+nose+rings |isbn=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=216 |pages= |year=1883 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=T. Woolmer |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=H. V. P. Bronkhurst |title=The Colony of British Guyana and Its Labouring Population: Containing a Short Account of the Colony, and Brief Descriptions of the Black Creole, Portuguese, East Indian, and Chinese Coolies … Collected … from Sundry Articles Published … at Different Times, and Arranged |url=https://books.google.com/?id=-zIsAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA216&dq=coolies+nose+rings |isbn=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=569 |pages= |year=1893 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=Ontario Publishing Company |volume= |issn= |edition= |others=J. Gordon Mowat, John Alexander Cooper, Newton MacTavish |title=The Canadian Magazine of Politics, Science, Art and Literature, Volume 1 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=3Lo6AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA569&dq=coolies+nose+rings+bangles |isbn=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=248 |pages= |year=1892 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=Macmillan |volume= |issn= |edition=2, reprint |author1=Marianne North |author2=Janet Catherine North Symonds |others= |quote= |location= |title=Recollections of a Happy Life: Being the Autobiography of Marianne North, Volume 2 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=Ig5FAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA248&dq=coolies+nose+rings+bangles |isbn=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=495 |pages= |year=1908 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher= |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=British Guiana |quote= |location= |title=The Official Gazette of British Guiana, Volume 27 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=5exCAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA495&dq=coolies+nose+rings+bangles |isbn=}}</ref>
In Port of Spain in Trinidad, Chinese coolies were described as going about almost naked while Indian coolie women wore "scanty drapery" and had "arms and ankles covered with bangles".<ref>{{cite book |page=179 |pages= |year=1885 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=Cassell & Company, Limited |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=William Bury Westall |title=Ralph Norbreck's Trust |url=https://books.google.com/?id=MgwGAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA179&dq=coolies+bangles |isbn=}}</ref>
One Indian woman on the way to Guiana had to be given jewelry like bangles made of silver and nose rings made of gold to by her husband in order to make her not leave him.<ref>{{cite book |page=73 |pages= |year=2013 |accessdate=1 June 2006 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |volume= |issn= |edition= |author=Gaiutra Bahadur |title=Coolie Woman: The Odyssey of Indenture |url=https://books.google.com/?id=iYBQAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA73&dq=coolies+bangles |isbn=0-226-04338-X}}</ref>
=== Peru === {{See also|Chinese Peruvian}}
About 100,000 Cantonese-Chinese coolies (almost all males) in 1849 to 1874 migrated to Peru and intermarried with Peruvian women of mestizo, European, Amerindian, European/mestizo, African and mulatto origin. Many Peruvian Chinese today are of mixed Chinese, Spanish, African, Amerindian. Estimates for Chinese-Peruvian is about 1.3 – 1.6 millions. Asian Peruvians are estimated to be 3% of the population, but one source places the number of citizens with some Chinese ancestry at 4.2 million, which equates to 15% of the country's total population. In Peru non-Chinese women married the mostly male Chinese coolies.<ref>{{cite book |page= |edition=illustrated |pages= |year=2011 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |volume=Volume 4 of Wiley Blackwell Concise History of the Modern World |author=Teresa A. Meade |title=A History of Modern Latin America: 1800 to the Present |url=https://books.google.com/?id=b4oyihfIfh0C&pg=PT148&dq=chinese+guyana+marry+east+indian+women |isbn=1-4443-5811-1}}</ref>
There were almost no women among the nearly entirely male Chinese coolie population that migrated to Peru and Cuba.<ref>{{cite book |page=143 |pages= |year=2010 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=BRILL |volume= |author=Isabelle Lausent-Herrera |editor1=Walton Look Lai |editor2=Chee Beng Tan |title=The Chinese in Latin America and the Caribbean |series=Brill ebook titles |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xrGShVU6VrgC&pg=PA143 |isbn=90-04-18213-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=47 |edition=illustrated |pages= |year=2001 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |volume= |author=Adam McKeown |author-link=Adam McKeown|title=Chinese Migrant Networks and Cultural Change: Peru, Chicago, and Hawaii 1900–1936 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=vix_3doZkH0C&pg=PA47&dq=chinese+peru+women |isbn=0-226-56025-2}}</ref> Peruvian women were married to these Chinese male migrants.<ref>{{cite book |page=75 |pages= |year=1999 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=Temple University Press |volume= |author=Robert G. Lee |title=Orientals: Asian Americans in Popular Culture |url=https://books.google.com/?id=mAZWspa5kPQC&pg=PA75&dq=chinese+peruvian+women |isbn=1-4399-0571-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=47 |edition=illustrated |pages= |year=2004 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=Hong Kong University Press |volume= |author=Chee-Beng Tan |title=Chinese Overseas: Comparative Cultural Issues |url=https://books.google.com/?id=Ca7UAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA47&dq=chinese+peruvian+women |isbn=962-209-661-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=181 |pages= |year=2002 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=Temple University Press |volume= |author1=Josephine D. Lee |author2=Imogene L. Lim |author3=Yuko Matsukawa |title=Re/collecting Early Asian America: Essays in Cultural History |url=https://books.google.com/?id=fjeAaEqo-CEC&pg=PA181&dq=chinese+peruvian+women |isbn=1-4399-0120-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=8 |edition=illustrated |pages= |year=1998 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=Press, University of the West Indies |volume= |author=Walton Look Lai |others=Walton Look Lai |quote= |location= |title=The Chinese in the West Indies, 1806–1995: A Documentary History |url=https://books.google.com/?id=fMrit6tcO_AC&pg=PA8&dq=walton+look+lai+caribbean+chinese+indian+women |isbn=976-640-021-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page= |pages= |year=2014 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=University of Texas Press |volume= |author=Michael J. Gonzales |quote= |location= |title=Plantation Agriculture and Social Control in Northern Peru, 1875–1933 |series= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=oKt0BQAAQBAJ&pg=PT139&dq=Ofthe+hundreds+of+thousandsof+Chinese+who+emigrated+to+the+New+World,+onlyahandful+were+women.+Of+the+100,000+Chinese+who+came+toPeru,+for+example,+only+15+were+women,+and+in+Cuba,+the+census+of+1872lists+only+32+Chinese+women+... |isbn=1-4773-0602-1}}</ref> African women particularly had mostly no intercourse with Chinese men during their labor as coolies, while Chinese had contact with Peruvian women in cities, there they formed relationships and sired mixed babies, these women originated from Andean and coastal areas and did not originally come from the cities, in the haciendas on the coast in rural areas, native young women of indígenas (native) and serranas (mountain) origin from the Andes mountains would come down to work, these Andean native women were favored as marital partners by Chinese men over Africans, with matchmakers arranging for communal marriages of Chinese men to indígenas and serranas young women.<ref>{{cite book |page=144 |pages= |year=2010 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=BRILL |volume= |author=Isabelle Lausent-Herrera |editor1=Walton Look Lai |editor2=Chee Beng Tan |quote= |location= |title=The Chinese in Latin America and the Caribbean |series=Brill ebook titles |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xrGShVU6VrgC&pg=PA144 |isbn=90-04-18213-6}}</ref> There was a racist reaction by Peruvians to the marriages of Peruvian women and Chinese men.<ref>{{cite book |page=145 |pages= |year=2010 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=BRILL |volume= |author=Isabelle Lausent-Herrera |editor1=Walton Look Lai |editor2=Chee Beng Tan |quote= |location= |title=The Chinese in Latin America and the Caribbean |series=Brill ebook titles |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xrGShVU6VrgC&pg=PA145 |isbn=90-04-18213-6}}</ref> When native Peruvian women (cholas et natives, Indias, indígenas) and Chinese men had mixed children, the children were called injerto and once these injertos emerged, Chinese men then sought out girls of injertas origins as marriage partners, children born to black mothers were not called injertos.<ref>{{cite book |page=146 |pages= |year=2010 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=BRILL |volume= |author=Isabelle Lausent-Herrera |editor1=Walton Look Lai |editor2=Chee Beng Tan |quote= |location= |title=The Chinese in Latin America and the Caribbean |series=Brill ebook titles |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xrGShVU6VrgC&pg=PA146 |isbn=90-04-18213-6}}</ref> Low class Peurvians established sexual unions or marriages with the Chinese men and some black and Indian women "bred" with the Chinese according to Alfredo Sachettí, who claimed the mixing was causing the Chinese to suffer from "progressive degeneration", in Casa Grande highland Indian women and Chinese men participated in communal "mass marriages" with each other, arranged when highland women were brought by a Chinese matchmaker after receiving a down payment.<ref>{{cite book |page= |pages= |year=2014 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=University of Texas Press |volume= |author=Michael J. Gonzales |quote= |location= |title=Plantation Agriculture and Social Control in Northern Peru, 1875–1933 |series= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=oKt0BQAAQBAJ&pg=PT139&dq=chinese+peru+women |isbn=1-4773-0602-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=100 |pages= |year=1985 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=University of Texas Press |issue=Issue 62 of Latin American Monographs, No 62, Issue 62 of Institute of Latin American Studies |volume=Volume 62 of Texas Pan American Series |author=Michael J. Gonzales |quote= |location= |title=Plantation Agriculture and Social Control in Northern Peru, 1875–1933 |series=Brill ebook titles |url=https://books.google.com/?id=I6-zAAAAIAAJ&q=when+recruits+arrived+placed+room+grooms+lined+up+opposite+highland+women+faces+each+directly+opposite+woman+contractor+claps+hand+signal+turn+around+man+wife+permits&dq=when+recruits+arrived+placed+room+grooms+lined+up+opposite+highland+women+faces+each+directly+opposite+woman+contractor+claps+hand+signal+turn+around+man+wife+permits |isbn=0-292-76491-X}}</ref>
In Peru and Cuba some Indian (Native American), mulatto, black, and white women engaged in carnal relations or marriages with Chinese men, with marriages of mulatto, black, and white woman being reported by the Cuba Commission Report and in Peru it was reported by the New York Times that [[Women in Peru|Peruvian black and Indian (Native) women]] married [[Chinese Peruvian|Chinese men]] to their own advantage and to the disadvantage of the men since they dominated and "subjugated" the Chinese men despite the fact that the labor contract was annulled by the marriage, reversing the roles in marriage with the Peruvian woman holding marital power, ruling the family and making the Chinese men slavish, docile, "servile", "submissive" and "feminine" and commanding them around, reporting that "Now and then...he [the Chinese man] becomes enamored of the charms of some sombre-hued chola (Native Indian and mestiza woman) or samba (mixed black woman), and is converted and joins the Church, so that may enter the bonds of wedlock with the dusky señorita."<ref>{{cite book |page=82 |edition=illustrated |pages= |year=2014 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=UNC Press Books |volume=Volume 4 of Wiley Blackwell Concise History of the Modern World |author=Elliott Young |quote= |location= |title=Alien Nation: Chinese Migration in the Americas from the Coolie Era Through World War II |series=The David J. Weber Series in the New Borderlands History |url=https://books.google.com/?id=ch8VBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA82&dq=indian+coolie+woman+chinese+men |isbn=1-4696-1296-8}}</ref> Chinese men were sought out as husbands and considered a "catch" by the "dusky damsels" (Peruvian women) because they were viewed as a "model husband, hard-working, affectionate, faithful and obedient" and "handy to have in the house", the Peruvian women became the "better half" instead of the "weaker vessel" and would command their Chinese husbands "around in fine style" instead of treating them equally, while the labor contract of the Chinese coolie would be nullified by the marriage, the Peruvian wife viewed the nullification merely as the previous "master" handing over authority over the Chinese man to her as she became his "mistress", keeping him in "servitude" to her, speedily ending any complaints and suppositions by the Chinese men that they would have any power in the marriage.<ref>{{cite news |author=From an Occasional Correspondent |date=28 June 1873 |title=THE COOLIE TRADE.; THE SLAVERY OF THE PRESENT. THE TRAFFIC OF PERU HIRING OF THE COO- LIE HORRORS OF THE MIDDLE PASSAGE THE COOLIE'S FATE. |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B0DE2D61539EF34BC4152DFB1668388669FDE |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150701053253/http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B0DE2D61539EF34BC4152DFB1668388669FDE |archivedate=1 July 2015 |newspaper=New York Times |location=CALLAO, Peru |access-date=17 May 2014}}</ref>
=== Cuba === {{See also|Chinese Cuban}} 120,000 Cantonese coolies (all males) entered Cuba under contract for 80 years, most did not marry, but Hung Hui (1975) cites there was frequent sexual activity between black women and Cantonese coolies. According to Osberg (1965) the free Chinese conducted the practice of buying slave women and freeing them expressly for marriage. In the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, Chinese men (Cantonese) engaged in sexual activity with white Cuban women and black Cuban women, and from such relations many children were born.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.upf.edu/mon/assig/xialmo/mat/dorsey_4.pdf |doi=10.1177/0094582X04264492 |title=Identity, Rebellion, and Social Justice Among Chinese Contract Workers in Nineteenth-Century Cuba |year=2004 |last1=Dorsey |first1=Joseph C. |journal=Latin American Perspectives |volume=31 |issue=3 |pages=18–47 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220035052/http://www.upf.edu/mon/assig/xialmo/mat/dorsey_4.pdf |archivedate=20 February 2012}}</ref>
In the 1920s an additional 30,000 Cantonese and small groups of Japanese also arrived; both immigrations were exclusively male, and there was rapid intermarriage with white, black, and mulato populations.<ref>{{cite book |author=David Stanley |title=Cuba: a Lonely Planet travel survival kit |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9HpqAAAAMAAJ |year=1997 |publisher=Lonely Planet |isbn=978-0-86442-403-7}}</ref>
In the study of Genetic origin, admixture, and asymmetry in maternal and paternal human lineages in Cuba. Thirty-five Y-chromosome SNPs were typed in the 132 male individuals of the Cuban sample. The study does not include any people with some Chinese ancestry. All the samples were White Cubans and Black Cubans. 2 out of 132 male sample belong to East Asian Haplogroup O2 which is found in significant frequencies among Cantonese people is found in 1.5% of Cuban population.<ref>{{cite journal |pmc=2492877 |title=Genetic origin, admixture, and asymmetry in maternal and paternal human lineages in Cuba |pmid=18644108 |year=2008 |last1=Mendizabal |first1=I |last2=Sandoval |first2=K |last3=Berniell-Lee |first3=G |last4=Calafell |first4=F |last5=Salas |first5=A |last6=Martínez-Fuentes |first6=A |last7=Comas |first7=D |volume=8 |page=213 |doi=10.1186/1471-2148-8-213 |journal=BMC Evolutionary Biology}}</ref>
=== Mexico === {{See also|Chinese immigration to Mexico}} The Chinese who migrated to Mexico in the 19th to 20th centuries were almost entirely Chinese men. Males made up the majority of the original Chinese community in Mexico and they married Mexican women.<ref>{{cite book |page=68 |pages= |year=2010 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=BRILL |volume= |author=Isabelle Lausent-Herrera |editor1=Walton Look Lai |editor2=Chee Beng Tan |quote= |location= |title=The Chinese in Latin America and the Caribbean |series=Brill ebook titles |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xrGShVU6VrgC&pg=PA68#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn=9004182136}}</ref> They married Mexican women, which led to anti-Chinese prejudice; many were expelled, while those who were allowed to stay intermarried with the Mexican population. The Mexicali officials estimate was that slightly more than 2,000 are full-blooded Chinese and about 8,000 are mixed-blood Chinese-Mexicans. Other estimates claimed 50,000 residents more than thought who are of Chinese descent. 10,000 full-blooded Chinese, down from 35,000 in the 1920s.<ref name="ivpressonline.com">[http://www.ivpressonline.com/articles/2010/06/20/local_news/news01.txt]{{dead link|date=April 2014}}</ref> Marriage of these people to full-blooded Mexicans is diluting the community further.<ref name="ivpressonline.com" /> Chinese Mexicans in Mexicali consider themselves equally "cachanilla," a term used for locals, as any other resident of the city, even if they speak Cantonese in addition to Spanish. The sentiment against Chinese men was due to (and almost all Chinese immigrants in Mexico were men) stealing employment and Mexican women from Mexican men who had gone off to fight in the Revolution or in World War I.<ref name="camacho552553">{{cite journal |last1=Schiavone Camacho |first1=Julia Maria |date=November 2009 |title=Crossing Boundaries, Claiming a Homeland: The Mexican Chinese Transpacific Journey to Becoming Mexican, 1930s–1960s |journal=Pacific Historical Review |place=Berkeley |volume=78 |issue=4 |pages=552–553 |doi=10.1525/phr.2009.78.4.545}}</ref>
=== Costa Rica === {{See also|Chinese people in Costa Rica}} The Chinese originated from the Cantonese male migrants. Pure Chinese make up only 1% of the Costa Rican population, but according to [[Jacqueline M. Newman]], as close to 10% of the people in Costa Rica are Chinese, if we count the people who are Chinese, married to a Chinese person, or of mixed Chinese descent.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Newman, Jacqueline M. |url=http://www.flavorandfortune.com/dataaccess/article.php?ID=221 |title=Chinese Food in Costa Rica |journal=Flavor and Fortune |date=Spring 2000 |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=15–16}}</ref> Most Chinese immigrants since then have been Cantonese, but in the last decades of the 20th century, a number of immigrants have also come from Taiwan. Many men came alone to work and married Costa Rican women and speak Cantonese. However the majority of the descendants of the first Chinese immigrants no longer speak Cantonese and feel themselves to be Costa Ricans.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Margaret Tyler Mitchell |author2=Scott Pentzer |title=Costa Rica: A Global Studies Handbook |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0edCL8TY08gC&pg=PA249 |year=2008 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=978-1-85109-992-4 |pages=249–}}</ref> They married Tican women (a blend of Europeans, Caztizos, Mestizos, Indian, and Black).<ref>[http://philip.greenspun.com/cr/moon/people Costa Rica, People]. Philip.greenspun.com. Retrieved 9 May 2012.</ref> A Tican is also a White person with a small portion of non-white blood like Caztizos. The census of 1989 shows about 98% of Costa Ricans were either white, Castizos or Mestizos, with 80% being white or Caztizos.
===Venezuela === {{see also|Chinese Venezuelan}}
Marriages between European, Mestizo, Amerindians, and Africans was not uncommon in the past. Several thousand Chinese from [[Enping]] resided in the country. The Chinese were still largely viewed as a foreign population who married foreign brides but seldom integrated into Venezuelan society.<ref>The Enduring Legacy: Oil, Culture, and Society in Venezuela By Miguel Tinker Salas [https://books.google.com/books?id=_R5JkihMrXAC&pg=PA118&dq=Chinese+Venezuelan+brides&hl=en]</ref>
=== Jamaica === {{See also|Chinese Jamaicans}} When black and [[Indo-Jamaican|Indian women]] had children with [[Chinese Jamaicans|Chinese men]] the [[Chindian|children]] were called chaina raial in Jamaican English.<ref>{{cite book |page=103 |pages= |year=2002 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=University of the West Indies Press |volume= |issn= |edition= |author1=Frederic Gomes Cassidy |author2=Robert Brock Le Page |editor1=Frederic Gomes Cassidy |editor2=Robert Brock Le Page |quote= |location= |title=Dictionary of Jamaican English |url=https://books.google.com/?id=_lmFzFgsTZYC&pg=PA103&dq=jamaica+indian+women+chinese+men |isbn=976-640-127-6}}</ref> The Chinese community in Jamaica was able to consolidate because an openness to marrying Indian women was present in the Chinese since Chinese women were in short supply.<ref>{{cite book |page=228 |pages= |year=2011 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=UNESCO |volume=Volume 4 of General History of the Caribbean |issn= |edition=illustrated |editor1=Franklin W. Knight |editor2=K. O. Laurence |others=P. C. Emmer, Jalil Sued Badillo, Germán Carrera Damas, B. W. Higman, Bridget Brereton, Unesco |title=General History of the Caribbean: The long nineteenth century : nineteenth-century transformations |url=https://books.google.com/?id=_Fnigcq_wtwC&pg=PA228&dq=jamaica+indian+women+marry+chinese+men |isbn=92-3-103358-1}}</ref> Women sharing was less common among Indians in Jamaica according to [[Verene A. Shepherd]].<ref>{{cite book |page=171 |pages= |year=1995 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=McGill-Queen's Press – MQUP |volume=Volume 22 of McGill-Queen's studies in ethnic history |issn=0846-8869 |edition=illustrated |author=Brian L. Moore |title=Cultural Power, Resistance, and Pluralism: Colonial Guyana, 1838–1900 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=cx_9-X_-smoC&pg=PA171&dq=jamaica+indian+women+marry+chinese+men |isbn=0-7735-1354-X}}</ref> The small number of Indian women were fought over between Indian men and led to a rise in the amount of wife murders by Indian men.<ref>{{cite book |page=101 |pages= |year=1988 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=Psychology Press |volume=Volume 7, Issue 1 of Immigrants & minorities |issue=Issue 1 of Immigrants & minorities |issn= |edition=illustrated |author=Howard Johnson |editor=Howard Johnson |title=After the Crossing: Immigrants and Minorities in Caribbean Creole Society |url=https://books.google.com/?id=FyVQ0Hn-YjkC&pg=PA101&dq=jamaica+indian+women+marry+chinese+men |isbn=0-7146-3357-7}}</ref> Indian women made up 11 percent of the annual amount of Indian indentured migrants from 1845–1847 in Jamaica.<ref>{{cite book |page=156 |pages= |year=1999 |accessdate=1 June 2015 |publisher=University of Toronto Press |volume=Volume 7, Issue 1 of Immigrants & minorities |issue=Issue 1 of Immigrants & minorities |issn= |edition=illustrated |author=Alena Heitlinger |editor=Alena Heitlinger |quote= |location= |title=Émigré Feminism: Transnational Perspectives |url=https://books.google.com/?id=a5NdI_7h7HAC&pg=PA156&dq=jamaica+indian+women+marry+chinese+men |isbn=0-8020-7899-0}}</ref> Thousands of Chinese men (mostly Hakka) and Indian men married local Jamaican women. The study "Y-chromosomal diversity in Haiti and Jamaica: Contrasting levels of sex-biased gene flow" shows the paternal Chinese haplogroup O-M175 at a frequency of 3.8% in local Jamaicans ( non-Chinese Jamaicans) including the Indian H-M69 (0.6%) and L-M20 (0.6%) in local Jamaicans.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Simms TM, Wright MR, Hernandez M, etal |title=Y-chromosomal diversity in Haiti and Jamaica: contrasting levels of sex-biased gene flow |journal=American Journal of Physical Anthropology |volume=148 |issue=4 |pages=618–31 |date=August 2012 |pmid=22576450 |doi=10.1002/ajpa.22090}}</ref> Among the country's most notable Afro-Asians are [[reggae]] singers [[Sean Paul]], [[Tami Chynn]] and [[Diana King]].
== Africa and Middle East ==
=== Middle East and North Africa ===
Interracial marriage{{Failed verification|date=September 2016}} between [[Arab]] men and their non-Arab [[harem]] slave girls was common in the [[Arab world]] during the [[Arab slave trade]], which lasted throughout the [[Middle Ages]] and [[early modern period]].<ref name="bbc" /> Most of these slaves came from places such as [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] (mainly ''[[Zanj]]'') the [[North Caucasus]],<ref name="gmu" /> [[Central Asia]] (mainly [[Tatary|Tatars]]), and [[Western Europe|Western]], [[Southern Europe|Southern]] and [[Southeastern Europe]] (mainly Slavs from Serbia – ''[[Saqaliba]]'', Spain, France, Italy).<ref name="avalanchepress" /><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/british/empire_seapower/white_slaves_01.shtml History – British History in depth: British Slaves on the Barbary Coast]. BBC. Retrieved 22 June 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.city-journal.org/html/17_2_urbanities-thomas_jefferson.html Jefferson Versus the Muslim Pirates by Christopher Hitchens, City Journal Spring 2007]. City-journal.org. Retrieved 22 June 2013.</ref> The [[Barbary pirate]]s from North Africa captured and enslaved 1.25 million white slaves from [[Western Europe]] and [[North America]] between the 16th and 19th centuries.<ref name="osu" /><ref name="mediterranean" /> Outside the Arab world, it was also common for [[Muslim conquests|Arab conquerors]], [[Islamic economics in the world|traders]] and [[Geography in medieval Islam|explorers]] to intermarry with local females in the lands they conquered or traded with, in various different parts of Africa, Asia (see [[#Asia|Asia]] section) and Europe (see [[#Europe|Europe]] section).
From AD 839, [[Viking]] [[Varangian]] mercenaries who were in the service of the [[Byzantine Empire]], notably [[Harald III of Norway|Harald Sigurdsson]], campaigned in [[North Africa]], [[Jerusalem]] and other places in the [[Middle East]] during the [[Byzantine-Arab Wars]]. They interbred with the local population as spoils of warfare or through eventual settling with many [[Scandinavia]]n Viking men taking [[Arab]] or [[Anatolia]]n women as wives. There is [[archaeological]] evidence the Vikings had established contact with the city of [[Baghdad]], at the time the center of the [[Caliphate|Islamic Empire]], and connected with the populace there.<ref name="nationalgeographic1" /> Regularly plying the Volga with their trade goods (furs, tusks, seal fat, seal boats and notably female slaves; the one period in the history of the slave-trade when females were priced higher than males), the Vikings were active in the Arab slave trade at the time.<ref name="Smelly Old History: Vile Vikings" /> These slaves, most often Europeans that were captured from the coasts of Europe or during war periods,<ref>Mushin, D. (1998) [http://www.columbia.edu/itc/history/conant/mushin1998.pdf The Saqaliba Slaves in the Aghlabid State].</ref> and sold to Arabic traders in [[Al-Andalus]] and the [[Emirate of Sicily]].
Intermarriage was accepted in Arab society, though only if the husband was Muslim. It was a fairly common theme in medieval [[Arabic literature]] and [[Persian literature]]. For example, the [[Persian people|Persian]] poet [[Nizami Ganjavi|Nizami]], who married his Central Asian [[Kipchaks|Kipchak]] slave girl, wrote ''The Seven Beauties'' (1196). Its [[frame story]] involves a [[Persian Empire|Persian]] prince marrying seven foreign princesses, who are [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]], [[China|Chinese]], [[Indian subcontinent|Indian]], [[Khwarezm]]ian, [[Maghreb]]ian, [[Slavic peoples|Slavic]] and [[Tatars|Tartar]]. ''[[Hadith Bayad wa Riyad]]'', a 12th-century Arabic tale from [[Al-Andalus]], was a love story involving an [[Iberians|Iberian]] girl and a [[Damascus|Damascene]] man. The ''[[One Thousand and One Nights|Arabian Nights]]'' tale of "[[The Ebony Horse]]" involves the [[List of kings of Persia|Prince of Persia]], Qamar al-Aqmar, rescuing his lover, the Princess of [[Sana'a]], from the [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine Emperor]] who also wishes to marry her.<ref name="The Arabian Nights Encyclopedia" />
At times, some marriages would have a major impact on the politics of the region. The most notable example was the marriage of [[As-Salih Ayyub]], the [[Sultan]] of the [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] [[Ayyubid dynasty]], to [[Shajar al-Durr]], a slave of [[Turkic people|Turkic]] origin from Central Asia. Following her husband's death, she became the [[Sultana (title)|Sultana]] of [[Egypt]] and the first [[Mamluk]] ruler. Her reign marked the end of the Ayyubid dynasty and the beginning of the [[Mameluk]] era, when a series of former Mamluk slaves would rule over Egypt and occasionally other neighbouring regions.<ref name="historians" /><ref name="described" /><ref name="regarded" /><ref name="according" />
=== Elsewhere in Africa === [[File:Pres. Ian Khama of Botswana, cropped.jpg|thumb|[[President of Botswana|President]] [[Ian Khama]] of [[Botswana]], son of Motswana chief [[Sir Seretse Khama]] and Englishwoman [[Ruth Williams Khama]]]] [[Africa]] has a long history of interracial mixing with [[Arabs]] and later [[Europe]]ans having sexual relations with black Africans. [[Arabs]] played a big role in the African [[slave]] trade and unlike the trans-Atlantic trade most of the black African slaves in the Arab slave trade were women. Most of them were used as [[sex slave|sexual]] slaves by the Arab men and some were taken as wives.
In the former Lusophone Africa (now known as [[Angola]], [[Mozambique]] and [[Cape Verde]]) racial mixing between white [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] and black Africans was fairly common, especially in Cape Verde, where the majority of the population is of mixed descent.
There have been several cases of [[Chinese people|Chinese]] merchants and laborers marrying black African women as many Chinese workers were employed to build railways and other infrastructural projects in Africa. These labour groups were made up completely of men with very few Chinese women coming to [[Africa]]. In [[Réunion]] and [[Madagascar]], intermarriage between Chinese men of Cantonese origin and African women is not uncommon.<ref>{{harvnb|Pan|1994|p=157}}</ref>
==== Southern Africa ==== There is a significant mixed race population, the result of mostly European and African unions, in South Africa, called [[Coloured]]s. The term Coloured is also used to describe persons of mixed race in the neighbouring nation of Namibia, to refer to those of part Khoisan, part black and part white descent. The [[Baster]]s constitute a separate ethnic group that are sometimes considered a sub-group of the Coloured population of the country.
Some of the [[Xhosa people]] claim descent from white people. The royal family of the [[ImiDushane]], for example, is descended from Queen Gquma of the [[Mpondo]], a white orphan that was adopted by a Xhosa chief after a shipwreck killed her parents. She later married an Mpondo prince, became his [[Great Wife|great wife]], and served as queen during his reign as king of the Tshomane Mpondo.
Interracial marriage was banned under apartheid. Due to this, there was considerable opposition to the marriage between Sir [[Seretse Khama]], Paramount Chief of the [[Bamangwato]] Tswanas, and his eventual wife [[Ruth Williams Khama]], Lady Khama, even though Chief Khama was Motswana and not South African.
Today there are a number of high-profile interracial couples in Southern Africa, such as the unions of [[Mmusi Maimane]] (a black opposition politician who serves as the [[Leader of the Opposition]] of South Africa) and his white wife Natalie Maimane, [[Matthew Booth (soccer)|Matthew Booth]] (a white [[soccer]] player) and his wife Sonia Bonneventia (a black former Miss South Africa first princess and international model)<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/simonaustin/2009/08/south_africas_white_knight.html Simon Austin: South Africa's white knight]. BBC (2009-08-06). Retrieved 22 June 2013.</ref> and [[Bryan Habana]] (a coloured South African [[rugby union]] player) and his white wife Janine Viljoen.<ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/sport/bok-who-just-wants-to-give-back-1.674595 Bok who just wants to give back – IOL Sport]. IOL.co.za (2010-07-24). Retrieved 22 June 2013.</ref>
==== Mauritius ==== In the late 19th to early 20th century, [[Sino-Mauritian|Chinese men in Mauritius]] married [[Indo-Mauritian|Indian]] women due to both a lack of Chinese women and the higher numbers of Indian women on the island.<ref>{{cite book |page=199 |edition= |pages= |year=2009 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=BRILL |volume=Volume 1 of European expansion and indigenous response, v. 1 |author1=Marina Carter |author2=James Ng Foong Kwong |title=Abacus and Mah Jong: Sino-Mauritian Settlement and Economic Consolidation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SN53oTMjAyMC&pg=PA199 |isbn=90-04-17572-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |page=33 |edition= |pages= |year=2009 |accessdate=17 May 2014 |publisher=Oxford University Press |volume= |author=Paul Younger Professor Emeritus of Religious Studies McMaster University |title=New Homelands : Hindu Communities in Mauritius, Guyana, Trinidad, South Africa, Fiji, and East Africa: Hindu Communities in Mauritius, Guyana, Trinidad, with Indian women was unappealing to the original all male Chinese migrants yet they eventually had to establish sexual unions with Indian women since there were no Chinese women coming.<ref>{{cite |volume=Volume 1 of European expansion and indigenous response, v. 1 |author1=Marina Carter |author2=James Ng Foong Kwong |title=Abacus and Mah Jong: Sino-Mauritian Settlement and Economic ==== West Africa ==== In West Africa, a series of interracial marriages and relationships created a number of mixed race families in the various countries of the region.
In [[Sierra Leone]], marriages between representatives of British trading firms and princesses of the [[Sherbro people]] created a number of aristocratic families such as the [[Sherbro Tuckers]] and the [[Caulker (surname)|Sherbro Caulkers]]. Due to matrilineality, they have maintained their claims to their ancestral thrones.
In [[Benin]], meanwhile, the descendants of the Brazilian slavetrader [[Francisco Felix de Sousa]] and his harem of black consorts have contributed a number of prominent citizens. Figures such as a president ([[Paul-Emile de Souza]]) and a first lady ([[Thomas Boni Yayi#Personal life|Chantal de Souza Boni Yayi]], President de Souza's niece) are arguably the most notable of them.
In [[Ghana]], a number of founding fathers had relationships with foreigners of other races: [[Kwame Nkrumah]] married the Egyptian [[Copt]] [[Fathia Nkrumah]] and raised a family with her. Their children would go on to become politicians like their father. President Nkrumah's contemporary and sometime friend, [[Joe Appiah]], was himself married to the British debutante [[Peggy Cripps|Peggy Cripps Appiah]]. At the start of the 21st century, their descendants were being led by their only son, [[Kwame Anthony Appiah]]. In addition to this, Dr. [[J. B. Danquah]] had a son with a British woman during his time in Britain. He would go on to become noted actor [[Paul Danquah]].
In [[Gabon]], a woman by the name of Germaine Anina - daughter of a Gabonese tribal chief - married a Chinese trader and politician named Cheng Zhiping. Their son, [[Jean Ping]], went on to serve as a minister in his mother's native country.
Lastly, a number of the first ladies in [[Francophone West Africa]] have been French: [[Leopold Sedar Senghor#Personal life and death|Collette Hubert Senghor]] and [[Viviane Wade]] of [[Senegal]], and [[Dominique Ouattara]] of [[Ivory Coast]].
== Australia == {{See also|Demographics of Australia}}
The Australian Government does not release information on the ethnicities of marriage partners, but provide information on their countries of birth. * In 2009 there were 120,118 marriages recorded in Australia. About 42% involved at least one partner who was not Australian-born. * 15% of Australian-born women, and 17.4% of Australian-born men, married somebody who was not Australian-born. * American (68%), Greek (62%) and Irish-born (62%) women were the most likely to marry an Australian-born man than a man born elsewhere. * Indian (12%), Chinese (16%) and 'other South and East Asia'-born (16%) women were the least likely to marry an Australian-born man than a man born elsewhere. * American (63%), Lebanese (62%) and Irish-born (62%) men were the most likely to marry an Australian-born woman than a woman born elsewhere. * Chinese (2%), 'other North Asia' (7%) and Vietnamese-born (8%) men were the least likely to marry an Australian-born woman than a woman born elsewhere. * Chinese-born men were the most likely to marry a woman from the same country (91%).
[[Indigenous Australians]] have a high interracial marriage rate. According to the 2000 Census in 1996, 64% of all married or ''de facto'' married couples involving an Indigenous person were mixed (i.e., only one partner was indigenous). In 55% of such couples, the Indigenous partner was female.<ref name="4102.0" />
Most of the early Chinese-Australia population was formed by Cantonese migrants from Guangzhou and Taishan, including some from Fujian, who came during the goldrush period of the 1850s. Marriage records show that between the 1850s and around the start of the 20th century, there were about 2000 legal marriages between white women and migrant Chinese men in Australia's eastern colonies, probably with similar numbers involved in de facto relationships of various kinds (ex: cohabitation, sexual intimacy).<ref>[http://epress.anu.edu.au/anu_lives/transnational/html/ch07s02.html Australian wives in China]. Epress.anu.edu.au (1904-03-01). Retrieved 9 May 2012.</ref> The number of intermarriages declined, as stories of viciousness and the seduction of white women grew, mixed with opposition to intermarriage. Rallies against Chinese men taking white women became widespread, as many Australian men saw the Chinese men intermarrying and cohabiting with white women as a threat to the white race. In late 1878 there were 181 marriages between European women and Chinese men, and 171 couples cohabiting without matrimony, resulting in 586 Eurasian children.<ref>{{cite book |author1=G. W. Trompf |author2=Carole M. Cusack |author3=Christopher Hartney |title=Religion and Retributive Logic: Essays in Honour of Professor Garry W. Trompf |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DqgezQo551kC&pg=PA351 |year=2010 |publisher=BRILL |isbn=978-90-04-17880-9 |pages=351–}}</ref> Such numbers of intermarriage would continue until the 1880s and the 1930s.
